componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the FMC Technologies Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] Your host is Rob Cherry, Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Cherry, you may begin your conference.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statements issued yesterday can be found on our website. I would like to caution you with respect to any forwar
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statements issued yesterday can be found on our website. I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-looking statements made during this call. Although these forward-looking statements are based on our current views and assumptions regarding future events, future business conditions and the outlook for us based on currently available information, these forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by these statements. I refer you to our disclosures regarding risk factors in our SEC filings.
I will now turn the call over to Peter Kinnear, FMC Technologies Chairman and CEO.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2010 conference call. With me today are Bill Schumann, our CFO; John Gremp, our President and COO; and Bob Potter, our Executive Vice President. First, I will share with you some highlights from the quarter and
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2010 conference call. With me today are Bill Schumann, our CFO; John Gremp, our President and COO; and Bob Potter, our Executive Vice President. First, I will share with you some highlights from the quarter and the year. Bill will then provide you with the details on our financial performance and our outlook for 2011. Finally, we'll open up the call for your questions.
I'm pleased to say we had another strong quarter and finished the year with record results. Our fourth quarter earnings per share were $0.82, including a benefit of $0.13 from some tax items. We earned $3.06 for the full year. Our full year EPS was another all-time high and represented our eighth consecutive year of earnings growth since our IPO. 
In the quarter, the total company backlog rose 14% to $4.2 billion. This increase was led by $1.1 billion in subsea orders, including orders for 39 subsea trees. For 2010, our total company backlog increased 64%. This was the first full year increase since 2007. Our subsea backlog grew for the fourth consecutive quarter and now stands at $3.6 billion after starting the year at $2.0 billion. Our 2010 subsea inbound of $4.1 billion was a record for that business. It was driven by solid fundamentals in the Deepwater market such as favorable oil prices, rig fleet expansion, capital spending increases and international growth. The price of oil remained at a level that has been conducive to Deepwater economics. This strength is in the oil prices continued into 2011 and does not appear to be showing any signs of weakness.
Expansion of the Deepwater rig fleet is a critical enabler for our customers to expand our capacity to complete more subsea wells. After growing 27% since 2007, the fleet is expected to grow another 20% over the next two years. The reported 2011 capital spending estimates for the major oil companies shows an increase of almost 20%, driven in large part by Deepwater activity. Typically, the actual capital spending exceeds these early industry estimates.
The Deepwater market continues to grow internationally. In 2010, we received orders for projects offshore: Brazil, Nigeria, Angola, Russia, China and Norway. In 2011, we have potential subsea awards in all those locations, and in addition, there are other growth areas such as Australia where we expect some long-awaited offshore gas projects to be awarded. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, we've been executing our pre-moratorium backlog and have received a few new post-Macondo orders. However, the base will remain a risk for us until the permitting issues a resolve. The Gulf of Mexico was approximately 11% of our total revenue in 2010, and we expect that it will be an even lower percentage in 2011. Fortunately for us, the Gulf of Mexico region is being largely offset by the combined continued strength that I just mentioned in the large growing international markets. 
Overall, we believe the subsea market will remain robust. As we have suggested last quarter, we think that our 2011 subsea orders could equal the record we set in 2010. Our confidence is based on the market fundamentals, our strong customer alliances and on our technology leadership in areas like subsea processing.
Turning to our Surface Wellhead business, we had a strong fourth quarter for orders and sales. In fact, our Surface Wellhead orders in the fourth quarter were at the highest level since before the industry downturn. 
Shifting to our Energy Processing businesses, the ongoing strength in the North American land rig count combined with the associated pressure pumping activity in both liquids and gas shale plays continue to drive growth in our Fluid Control business. In fact, we had record Fluid Control revenue in the quarter and its backlog reached another all-time high. Our Fluid Control business has recovered substantially since the downturn in the industry. Sales in 2010 for Fluid Control were up 70% from 2009 and orders more than doubled. One of the key factors has been the successful market penetration of our Well Service Pump. After receiving almost no pump orders during the 2009 industry downturn, we booked record pump orders in 2010, and the near-term outlook for these pumps and other Fluid Control products remains very positive.
As for the other Energy Processing businesses, each one had sequential order growth in the fourth quarter, and we expect full year order growth in all these businesses for 2011. 
So let me just say in summary, we had a record year for earnings in subsea orders. The market fundamentals for Deepwater continue to be very, very positive for subsea, and we experienced record performance from our Fluid Control business. So let me now turn the call over to Bill Schumann.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Peter. Energy Production sales for the fourth quarter were $875 million, down 11% from last year but up 14% sequentially. The decrease from the prior year was mainly driven by a mix of early-stage subsea projects in our backlog relative to a year
componenttext:
Thanks, Peter. Energy Production sales for the fourth quarter were $875 million, down 11% from last year but up 14% sequentially. The decrease from the prior year was mainly driven by a mix of early-stage subsea projects in our backlog relative to a year ago. In contrast, the sequential increase is an indication that the rate of execution on subsea projects and backlog is increasing. 
Energy Production generated operating profit of $105 million in the quarter, down 20% from the prior year quarter, mainly due to lower subsea volume. Margins were 12% in the quarter and just under 15% for the full year. For 2011, we expect that the margin to be in the range of 12% to 13% with some fluctuation from quarter-to-quarter depending on timing and the effectiveness of our project execution. 
Inbound orders in Energy Production were $1.3 billion in the quarter, including subsea orders of $1.1 billion. This profit total subsea order amount for the year to a record $4.1 billion. We ended the year with a backlog of $3.9 billion dollars, including subsea backlog of $3.6 billion. Not included in these amounts were the recently announced Total Jerry, Statoil, G grid awards, which will all be booked in the first quarter of 2011.
Turning to Energy Processing, sales were $223 million, up 26% from the year-ago quarter. The increase was driven by our Fluid Control business led by our WECO/Chiksan Flowline Products and our Well Service Pumps as Peter described. Their sales together set a record due to continued strength of the North American pressure pumping activity. While the other Energy Processing businesses had lower sales in the quarter compared to last year, they were up 18% from the third quarter and all of them contributed to that increase. Energy Processing generated record operating profit of $43 million, more than double the prior year quarter. The increase was primarily the result of our record volume in Fluid Control. The fourth quarter margin of 19.5% was also a new record. In 2011, we expect the full year margin for this segment to be in a range of 17% to 18%. I would caution, however, that our Fluid Control business is subject to the volatility of the North American lane rig count and the pressure pumping market, and that can drive significant changes in this segment margin. 
Total inbound orders for Energy Processing reached an all-time high of $256 million, up 48% from last year's fourth quarter. The improvement was again driven by Fluid Control but was aided by order strength in Measurement Solutions also. Backlog ended the quarter at $296 million.
Now for the corporate items. Corporate expense in the quarter was $10.9 million. Other expense net was $3 million. This was less than we had anticipated due mainly to lower LIFO expenses. Our fourth quarter tax rate of 24.7% was impacted by a number of items, but we don't expect to repeat at least with the same impact as we experienced in the past quarter. The quarter included the resolution of an IRS tax appeal as previously announced; other changes in reserves for uncertain tax positions. Actions we took in the quarter related to changes in U.S. tax law that increased our tax expense; and the late receipt of confirmation for a tax incentive that we had anticipated receiving before year end. Removing these items from EPS would reduce earnings per share by $0.13 to $0.69 for the quarter.
Adjusting for these items still leaves us with a 36.3% tax rate in the quarter, which was still higher than anticipated due to the higher U.S. taxes on under distributed foreign earnings. For the full year 2010, the tax rate was 32.7% after adjusting for those special items. We did receive the letter of confirmation for the tax incentives in January. It is retroactive to 2009 but the tax benefit will be recorded in the first quarter of 2011. Our guidance for 2011 tax rate is at an annual rate of 30% to 32%, which excludes the first quarter tax incentive benefit of $7 million.
We ramped up our capital spending this quarter to $47 million, bringing the full year capital spending to $112 million. This ramp-up will continue into to this year as we expect capital spending in 2011 to be in excess of $200 million. Facility improvements planned for Brazil and Asia make up a large portion of this increase, along with the expansion of our Fluid Control facilities in North America. 
At the end of the quarter, we had net debt position of $48 million. This was comprised of $315 million of cash and $363 million of debt. We averaged $121.7 million diluted shares outstanding in the quarter due to a combination of the ramp-up in capital spending, an increase in pension funding and a desire to keep our net debt to the current level, we did not repurchase any shares in the quarter.
Turning to the overall outlook for 2011. We expect another strong year in subsea orders. As Peter mentioned, we could potentially reach the same record amount of orders as 2010, driving our subsea backlog to a record level. However, the situation in the Gulf presents a risk to that level of orders. On the top line, we expect improvement in all of our businesses even in Fluid Control, where we're coming off a record year in sales. Subsea and Surface Wellhead sales could also reach all-time highs. The Measurement Solutions and loading system sales will rebound and start to approach the levels they saw in 2008. The 2011 margins in Production will be in a range of 12% to 13%. In Processing, the 2011 margins will be in line with the 2010 average of 17% to 18%. And again, for earnings, our 2011 guidance for diluted EPS is $3.20 to $3.40 per share. Operator, you may now open up the call for questions.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on a couple of your guide points here on the margin front. Energy Processing 17% to 18% coming off at 19.5% fourth quarter run rate. Can you give us some insight as to now the ramp-down in margins that you expect in 2011?
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on a couple of your guide points here on the margin front. Energy Processing 17% to 18% coming off at 19.5% fourth quarter run rate. Can you give us some insight as to now the ramp-down in margins that you expect in 2011?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kurt. We mentioned that was a record quarter for us in terms of margins, and really what happened was Fluid Control had a strong quarter, actually a little bit stronger than the third quarter even, but the real differential here was the other busines
componenttext: Yes, Kurt. We mentioned that was a record quarter for us in terms of margins, and really what happened was Fluid Control had a strong quarter, actually a little bit stronger than the third quarter even, but the real differential here was the other businesses. Measurement and Loading Systems had an outstanding fourth quarter, and while we expect them to improve their full year performance in 2011, it's not going to be as strong as their fourth quarter performance. So we anticipate that the Fluid business in 2011 will grow kind of in-line with the rig count, and that the Loading and Measurement will improve their performance actually probably at the top line a little bit better than our Fluid Control business, and that will kind of dilute the margins a little bit. But in absolute terms, we're going to deliver increased earnings in the Energy Processing business in 2011.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing any slowdown whatsoever in the Frac Equipment business, any indications that the service companies feel there's enough capacity in the market at this point and are starting to ramp down their spend?
componenttext: Are you seeing any slowdown whatsoever in the Frac Equipment business, any indications that the service companies feel there's enough capacity in the market at this point and are starting to ramp down their spend?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kurt, Bob Potter. No, we continue to see a robust environment for the frac equipment, and obviously, there's a couple of really important reasons for that. One is rig count, which so far this year is averaging about 11% above the average for last year, an
componenttext: Kurt, Bob Potter. No, we continue to see a robust environment for the frac equipment, and obviously, there's a couple of really important reasons for that. One is rig count, which so far this year is averaging about 11% above the average for last year, and we're kind of expecting a similar number through the rest of the year in our guidance. And secondly, the frac intensity continues to increase. These operators have learned that there's not much incremental cost to additional frac stages longer laterals, and so kind of separated from rig count, we have the frac intensity increases, which are driving a lot of improvement in Fluid Control business as well.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the other follow-up I had on Energy Production margins, the indication of 12% to 13% range for '11 would imply that you think the fourth quarter was then your low point for margins in Energy Production. I just wondered if you could give us some insigh
componenttext: And the other follow-up I had on Energy Production margins, the indication of 12% to 13% range for '11 would imply that you think the fourth quarter was then your low point for margins in Energy Production. I just wondered if you could give us some insights as to your degree of confidence and how you drive that confidence into say the fourth quarter being your low point?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we've laid out our budget and our plans, there really isn't a quarter that sticks out as an obvious trough in margins. That being said, the second half of 2011 looks better than the first half. So I guess I'm not ready to call a quarter for the t
componenttext: Well, as we've laid out our budget and our plans, there really isn't a quarter that sticks out as an obvious trough in margins. That being said, the second half of 2011 looks better than the first half. So I guess I'm not ready to call a quarter for the trough.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: But that would indicate, though, that the pricing you've taken in some of these orders through 2010 you're starting to see some improvement in the pricing that's in backlog? Or is it all through cost control? Can you give us some insights on that?
componenttext: But that would indicate, though, that the pricing you've taken in some of these orders through 2010 you're starting to see some improvement in the pricing that's in backlog? Or is it all through cost control? Can you give us some insights on that?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we've gotten a little bit of both actually. We've made some improvements in our cost position that you've seen through 2010, and it looks as though we've got a little bit better pricing coming through probably the second half of the year in terms of
componenttext: Well, we've gotten a little bit of both actually. We've made some improvements in our cost position that you've seen through 2010, and it looks as though we've got a little bit better pricing coming through probably the second half of the year in terms of our execution. And we also probably benefit a little bit from leverage as we go through the year, leveraging the SG&A spend.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Mackenzie of ABR capital markets.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Peter, would you mind giving us some more color on what you're doing vis-a-vis your expansions and your CapEx from region to region, including in the Fluid Control segment?
componenttext: Peter, would you mind giving us some more color on what you're doing vis-a-vis your expansions and your CapEx from region to region, including in the Fluid Control segment?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, we formally announced investing in a technology center in Brazil, which we think is a great thing for us to do. We have been operating in Brazil since 1956 and have a great relationship with Petrobras, but they have a lot of particularly pre-salt a
componenttext: Sure, we formally announced investing in a technology center in Brazil, which we think is a great thing for us to do. We have been operating in Brazil since 1956 and have a great relationship with Petrobras, but they have a lot of particularly pre-salt a lot of new technology issues. So that's some capital going there. We're also reconfiguring our facility in Brazil to be a little bit more efficient particularly on the subsea manifold arena. So we're using some capital there. On the Fluid Control side, we have a major capital expansion going on to increase our capacity for Well Service Pumps as well as our Flowline products. And that's in our existing facilities, Texas, and that adds machine tools, as well as floor space and that sort of stuff. And then in the Far East, to continue to drive some of our low-cost items in sourcing, we are expanding in both Singapore and Malaysia in terms of our facilities there to continue to drive down our low-cost source strategy work. I think we've talked about before we've taken a lot of standard products that maybe we have made in two or three different plants and we moved all that one to one central location. And that certainly has improved our margin over time in the business. So we continue to invest there. And there may be some additional offshore tooling like well intervention systems net and service tools that we invest. So that's the bulk of it.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And my next question comes back to an outlook type question. Really not a lot of commentary early on about the outlook for separation, if you will. Can you give us some guidance on broadly on orders for the subsea business, but how much of that includes e
componenttext: And my next question comes back to an outlook type question. Really not a lot of commentary early on about the outlook for separation, if you will. Can you give us some guidance on broadly on orders for the subsea business, but how much of that includes expectations for future separation orders? And any change in your view of that market over the past couple of months?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rob, this is John. The subsea processing, which includes separation and boosting is -- I mean it continues as strong as we've seen it. Look out over the next two years and there's almost 15 named projects. Now some of them are strong or have a stronger pr
componenttext: Rob, this is John. The subsea processing, which includes separation and boosting is -- I mean it continues as strong as we've seen it. Look out over the next two years and there's almost 15 named projects. Now some of them are strong or have a stronger probability of actually happening rather than others, but that's as strong as we've seen it. There were two subsea processing awards last year. There's a potential for three to four this year. Some of them a little later this year so they could slip into 2012, but the list of names processing projects is as healthy as we've seen plus the number of feed studies, for us anyway, is almost doubled. So I think there's a trend, and there's some momentum gaining in terms of the operators being interested in processing. So I'd say it's very healthy, not the exact timing of these projects. As I said, some are stronger than others, but it's very encouraging.

Is that still the mass at work there? I think we came out some about three. I'm sorry.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's exactly right, Bill. I think you'll see the K come out, and we'll say that about 66% of the backlog in Energy Production is going to turn into revenue in 2011, but if you're just looking at subsea, it's closer to 60%. If you go through that arithme
componenttext: That's exactly right, Bill. I think you'll see the K come out, and we'll say that about 66% of the backlog in Energy Production is going to turn into revenue in 2011, but if you're just looking at subsea, it's closer to 60%. If you go through that arithmetic, you start with $3.6 billion. In backlog, you end up with $2.2 billion of revenue coming out of backlog. We think we'll get about $700 million in customer supporter or aftermarket services and then another $400 million of book in turn revenues for a total of $3.3 billion. We were at I think the same number we were at the third quarter call.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, Peter, you have recently converted strategic subsea launch we had with Shell turned enterprise frame agreement. Can you discuss what incrementally that brings to you and should we expect I guess more of these type of conversions going forward?
componenttext: I guess, Peter, you have recently converted strategic subsea launch we had with Shell turned enterprise frame agreement. Can you discuss what incrementally that brings to you and should we expect I guess more of these type of conversions going forward?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me let John answer that.
componenttext: Let me let John answer that.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're obviously excited about expanding the Shell Gulf of Mexico relationship that goes back almost 15 years globally. It's something we want to do for a long time, and it really started with BC Tan in Brazil where that was a direct award to us, and
componenttext: Yes, we're obviously excited about expanding the Shell Gulf of Mexico relationship that goes back almost 15 years globally. It's something we want to do for a long time, and it really started with BC Tan in Brazil where that was a direct award to us, and I think Shell clearly saw the benefit of moving the exclusive relationship beyond the Gulf of Mexico, so it was just natural that the enterprise frame agreement was the next logical step for our two companies. What it means in business is where its tendering is not required outside of our production sharing contract environment, we would expect that business to be direct awarded to us. So that's clearly a positive because we won't be competing for some of that business. In other cases where there's production sharing contractor environment in national oil companies and bidding is required, we'll still bid like we normally do but we'll obviously have some advantages in terms of equipment standardization, that sort of thing that should help us even in a bidding environment.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

componenttextpreview: Yes, we knew it was coming, and we also knew the acceleration of ramp-up was coming as fast as it did.
componenttext: Yes, we knew it was coming, and we also knew the acceleration of ramp-up was coming as fast as it did.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the frac intensity and all that stuff?
componenttext: And the frac intensity and all that stuff?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: The things are going well in the Pump business. Now we are continuing to add some product lines in the Fluid Control business, most notably the manifold trailers, what we call the articulated our manifold trailers, which are really gaining some traction i
componenttext: The things are going well in the Pump business. Now we are continuing to add some product lines in the Fluid Control business, most notably the manifold trailers, what we call the articulated our manifold trailers, which are really gaining some traction in the market right now. Anything that the pressure pumpers can get in their hands that's tied to safety, time and efficiency has got a great chance of succeeding in today's environment, and so that's kind of where our focus is.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Brian Uhlmer with Global Hunter.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on some of the questions Colin was asking in North America. Obviously, some of your guidance for 2011, I know you don't do a recount projection but what are your views on kind of the ramp-up in that activity and the growth in that
componenttext: I just want to follow up on some of the questions Colin was asking in North America. Obviously, some of your guidance for 2011, I know you don't do a recount projection but what are your views on kind of the ramp-up in that activity and the growth in that particular segment based on the North American business?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier we're kind of projecting rig count to be in the 1,700 to 1,750 range. The only material changes that we continue to see are the shift between gas-directed rigs and those in the liquid-rich environment. So Bakken, Marcellus, Eagle F
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier we're kind of projecting rig count to be in the 1,700 to 1,750 range. The only material changes that we continue to see are the shift between gas-directed rigs and those in the liquid-rich environment. So Bakken, Marcellus, Eagle Ford is getting a lot of concentration of activity. So for us, it's simply a matter of ensuring that our bases in those locations are ready to go for the market increase we expect to see.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And you're already fairly established in the basins?
componenttext: And you're already fairly established in the basins?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are.
componenttext: Yes, we are.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And with the ramp-up, first, I think it's conservative rig count forecast, but with the ramp up, do we believe that there will be pricing improvements and potential margin improvements in that particular segment of the business?
componenttext: And with the ramp-up, first, I think it's conservative rig count forecast, but with the ramp up, do we believe that there will be pricing improvements and potential margin improvements in that particular segment of the business?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I hope you're right with the rig count that it does go up above that. I think the focus that we have is trying to manage the supply chain very diligently right now as it becomes more and more called upon to supply increasingly greater
componenttext: Well, first of all, I hope you're right with the rig count that it does go up above that. I think the focus that we have is trying to manage the supply chain very diligently right now as it becomes more and more called upon to supply increasingly greater levels of products. So that's our challenge. We think we're doing a reasonable job of that now. Obviously, pricing is something that we continually look at to ensure that our margins are maintained.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving on to subsea and kind of the rig count growth that we see in offshore, are we projecting or are you projecting as we move out further on 2011 and maybe obviously there's a little bit longer timeframe but out into 2012, that the efficiencies that we
componenttext: Moving on to subsea and kind of the rig count growth that we see in offshore, are we projecting or are you projecting as we move out further on 2011 and maybe obviously there's a little bit longer timeframe but out into 2012, that the efficiencies that we've gained in offshore drilling that you can actually grow an excess of the percentage growth in the actual number of rigs drilling? Is that a fair outlook for 2012?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say yes, it's a fair outlook. We run trees on wire independent of the trees, the rig sometimes. The industry's always looking for ways to be more efficient that can gain better utilization of the assets offshore. And so we've been pretty prog
componenttext: Yes, I would say yes, it's a fair outlook. We run trees on wire independent of the trees, the rig sometimes. The industry's always looking for ways to be more efficient that can gain better utilization of the assets offshore. And so we've been pretty progressive in helping that strategy take place.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you feel that, not to put words in your mouth, but a 20% growth from 2011 earnings to 2012 earnings isn't that excessively aggressive?
componenttext: So you feel that, not to put words in your mouth, but a 20% growth from 2011 earnings to 2012 earnings isn't that excessively aggressive?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, it depends on the CapEx spending individual projects, timing of the projects, but our subsea business is historically except for the dip in '08, we had growth in 20-plus percent per year, so certainly that's achievable.
componenttext: Yes, well, it depends on the CapEx spending individual projects, timing of the projects, but our subsea business is historically except for the dip in '08, we had growth in 20-plus percent per year, so certainly that's achievable.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Daniel Boyd with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Daniel Boyd with Goldman Sachs.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Peter, I was hoping to just follow up with some of the comments made about the Gulf of Mexico. You have booked some awards post-Macondo. I think we saw one in late December from Shell, but now it looks like Shell might be close to getting a permit for tha
componenttext: Peter, I was hoping to just follow up with some of the comments made about the Gulf of Mexico. You have booked some awards post-Macondo. I think we saw one in late December from Shell, but now it looks like Shell might be close to getting a permit for that. But how are the conversations with customers progressed over past few months? Has there been any change at all?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's kind of a mixed bag a little bit. We see some dialogue with the government on the well containment issue, which probably is one of the stumbling blocks. What do we have to have in place for the government to get comfortable there? And y
componenttext: Well, I think it's kind of a mixed bag a little bit. We see some dialogue with the government on the well containment issue, which probably is one of the stumbling blocks. What do we have to have in place for the government to get comfortable there? And yes, I think the operators that have major positions, I think they're assuming it's kind of get worked out, and therefore, let's not lose one or two years on schedule and let's be smart here and plan ahead. And so like Shell, we're getting orders in advance in anticipation that the moratorium gets lifted and then go back to drilling. Other customers a little bit more cautious. We had a Phase II with Petrobras in their cascade project in the Gulf of disco that they were just about to give us that award just before the Macondo situation. It kind of pulled back, so now we're going to wait and see what happens. So it's still kind of a mixed bag from that standpoint, but fortunately, we've diversified our portfolio and shifted quite a bit of our use of resources onto international projects. And so we're weathering through the situation quite well and anticipate that the Gulf of Mexico comes back and that we're going to need the oil and gas produced from Deepwater.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Did you have any insight on maybe where the industry is on the well containment solution? Or and did you like to offer publicly?
componenttext: Did you have any insight on maybe where the industry is on the well containment solution? Or and did you like to offer publicly?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there's two solutions out there, one by the majors and one by Helix that try to do the same thing a little bit different way. And so it's good. We think those will both be assessed, and you could see smaller independents are working kind of helix,
componenttext: I think there's two solutions out there, one by the majors and one by Helix that try to do the same thing a little bit different way. And so it's good. We think those will both be assessed, and you could see smaller independents are working kind of helix, the bigger guys are working on the marine well containment company. And so you could see a consolidation of all that under one system once the government decides one's better than the other.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Simpson with Miller Tabak.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Simpson with Miller Tabak.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to drill down a little bit more on that the Gulf of Mexico impact on the potential order flow first. In the guidance, is there anything incremental to Shell i.e. maybe the cascade project that is in if you need that to get that $4 billion
componenttext: I guess I wanted to drill down a little bit more on that the Gulf of Mexico impact on the potential order flow first. In the guidance, is there anything incremental to Shell i.e. maybe the cascade project that is in if you need that to get that $4 billion kind of level for orders for this year?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we've discounted the order rate in '11 for the Gulf pretty heavily, so our orders assumes that not too much happens in terms of new orders.
componenttext: No, we've discounted the order rate in '11 for the Gulf pretty heavily, so our orders assumes that not too much happens in terms of new orders.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And maybe a quick update on the Marlim system. When is that likely to be installed?
componenttext: And maybe a quick update on the Marlim system. When is that likely to be installed?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: John can give you an update on Marlim.
componenttext: John can give you an update on Marlim.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kevin, it's scheduled to be delivered in the third quarter and installed I think also towards the very end of the third quarter, so on schedule. We completed most of the qualification that were required, and so far Petrobas has been very pleased with our
componenttext: Kevin, it's scheduled to be delivered in the third quarter and installed I think also towards the very end of the third quarter, so on schedule. We completed most of the qualification that were required, and so far Petrobas has been very pleased with our progress. So we look forward to getting it into the water. It's a pilot and pretty important to Petrobras for their future, so I know they're anxious to see the system operate.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And do you think it's unrealistically kind of too soon to assume that you could capture 12 for similar systems based out of Petrobras if the Marlim system works as planned?
componenttext: And do you think it's unrealistically kind of too soon to assume that you could capture 12 for similar systems based out of Petrobras if the Marlim system works as planned?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Again, we don't know how long the evaluation period's going to be. We don't know. Clearly, there are future requirements for this kind of system in Brazil. They're evaluating a number of different technologies, so it's not -- Marlim is certainly, but they
componenttext: Again, we don't know how long the evaluation period's going to be. We don't know. Clearly, there are future requirements for this kind of system in Brazil. They're evaluating a number of different technologies, so it's not -- Marlim is certainly, but they're looking at other processing systems. They came out with the bid for their Congo project, which is also boosting. So there, it's clear that Petrobras is gaining confidence in this technology and are determined to implement it. But just select when they're going to be when they're going to actually start issuing orders on a larger basis beyond the pilot, I think that's difficult to say. They need time to do their evaluation, but there's no question that they're getting confident with the technology, and this is a key trend in Brazil to apply processing to increase their oil recovery.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then one quick one for Bob. We'll put Bob against Bill. It sounds it just seems like the guidance vis-a-vis Processing and Fluid Control particularly sounds like it's on the conservative side. Are you guys capacity-constrained? Is that kind of some of
componenttext: And then one quick one for Bob. We'll put Bob against Bill. It sounds it just seems like the guidance vis-a-vis Processing and Fluid Control particularly sounds like it's on the conservative side. Are you guys capacity-constrained? Is that kind of some of the issues in terms of how much increment you can get from Fluid Control in '11 given the substantial, the penetration relative to rig count that we're still seeing in Fracs business?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm actually going to agree with Bill here. As he said, Fluid Control is actually increasing year-over-year. Peter talked about the capacity expansion, which we're adding as quickly as we possibly can. But the bigger effect is the other Processing busines
componenttext: I'm actually going to agree with Bill here. As he said, Fluid Control is actually increasing year-over-year. Peter talked about the capacity expansion, which we're adding as quickly as we possibly can. But the bigger effect is the other Processing businesses, particularly loading and Measurement are expecting a much better years in 2011. And as Bill talked about, that'll have a bit of a dilutive effect on the overall margin segment.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Brad Handler with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Brad Handler with Credit Suisse.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you first speak to I guess use of cash? Bill, I think you made a comment I wasn't quite sure I heard it but you didn't repurchase shares in the quarter because you liked your net debt position? Can you first confirm that, that's what you said and ma
componenttext: Could you first speak to I guess use of cash? Bill, I think you made a comment I wasn't quite sure I heard it but you didn't repurchase shares in the quarter because you liked your net debt position? Can you first confirm that, that's what you said and maybe speak to how much share repurchase you might be targeting in your guidance for 2011, for example or I guess a diluted share count would get at that to?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I don't think I said I liked the debt level, but we had quite a few cash requirements in the fourth quarter. We ramped up spending, and as I mentioned capital spending, that is. That's going to continue to ramp up throughout 2011. We had pretty
componenttext: Well, yes, I don't think I said I liked the debt level, but we had quite a few cash requirements in the fourth quarter. We ramped up spending, and as I mentioned capital spending, that is. That's going to continue to ramp up throughout 2011. We had pretty significant pension funding during the year. We've put about $39 million into our combination of U.S. and foreign pension plans, and we had a working capital build in the quarter also. So we kind of maintained our debt level at about the current rate. We ended the year at 48, but our cash allocation has not changed. We want to support the growth of the business. That's our first priority. Second priority is acquisitions. And our third priority, if we have any cash left over, is repurchase of stock. We repurchased I think $168 million in 2010. We kind of expect a similar level of stock repurchase and maybe a little bit higher actually in 2011, and that will have the result in reduction of shares outstanding. The shares outstanding impact on the earnings guidance really isn't significant if you go through the arithmetic though.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe speak to the acquisition landscape a little bit guys? Personally, that includes Bob and outside of the subsea world as well. But how's the bid-ask spread looking now relative to six or nine months ago? What is your general optimism that you will fin
componenttext: Maybe speak to the acquisition landscape a little bit guys? Personally, that includes Bob and outside of the subsea world as well. But how's the bid-ask spread looking now relative to six or nine months ago? What is your general optimism that you will find some opportunities here in the M&A front?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. Some of the properties you've seen being purchased have gone for quite high prices have the most recent GE one. It seems to be in the same range, so I think there's still opportunities out there. We've done another a number of smal
componenttext: That's a good question. Some of the properties you've seen being purchased have gone for quite high prices have the most recent GE one. It seems to be in the same range, so I think there's still opportunities out there. We've done another a number of small deals that kind of were bolt-on acquisition deals for us that have been very successful, the little multi-phased meter company that we bought in Norway. In the year, we doubled our revenue in terms of exposure to our large customer base. And so those things are from an incremental payback and return are great. But hard to find, and I have to find the right niche in the right company. The bigger deals, we certainly participate and look at those, and the number's got to have to be right for us before we pull the trigger. So the deals have been pretty expensive in our point of view so far.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Unrelated question please last for me. Could you give us a little bit more color on the sources of optimism about growth, maybe particularly in the loading area? Is that FPSO-driven? Or where are you seeing those opportunities?
componenttext: Unrelated question please last for me. Could you give us a little bit more color on the sources of optimism about growth, maybe particularly in the loading area? Is that FPSO-driven? Or where are you seeing those opportunities?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Bob again. The LNG market is for our loading arms is recovering nicely in 2011 particularly in areas like Australia. There's a big one in Singapore. There's a big one in India, so that's going along well. And also, to your point, their floati
componenttext: Yes, this is Bob again. The LNG market is for our loading arms is recovering nicely in 2011 particularly in areas like Australia. There's a big one in Singapore. There's a big one in India, so that's going along well. And also, to your point, their floating LNG environment is beginning to gain momentum, and that's a particularly important market segment for us.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And some of the inbound intend reflected LNG already?
componenttext: And some of the inbound intend reflected LNG already?

componenttext: Yes, there will be some inbound reflected. I'm sorry, the inbound in '11 will reflect the orders in LNG. '10 was pretty modest in that regard.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Gibney with Capital One Southcoast.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Gibney with Capital One Southcoast.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bill, I was wondering if you could help me out a look with your other expense line item. You referenced lower LIFO expense this quarter. I know normalized run rate could be significant higher $10 million to $11 million per quarter. Could you help us some
componenttext: Bill, I was wondering if you could help me out a look with your other expense line item. You referenced lower LIFO expense this quarter. I know normalized run rate could be significant higher $10 million to $11 million per quarter. Could you help us some expectations in '11 on that front?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wish I could just -- it'd be '11 every quarter, but unfortunately, there's always some impacts that foreign currency flows through there. But in general, in the fourth quarter, the biggest issue was LIFO adjustment, and we had estimated a little bit hig
componenttext: I wish I could just -- it'd be '11 every quarter, but unfortunately, there's always some impacts that foreign currency flows through there. But in general, in the fourth quarter, the biggest issue was LIFO adjustment, and we had estimated a little bit higher ending inventory levels throughout the year, and we had also estimated higher inflation. And we do a survey in the fourth quarter, and that survey resulted in lower inflation. We ended with lower inventory. Consequently, the adjustment at the end in the fourth quarter was very low. And that was the major reason for the, if you will, $8 million difference between our normal guidance of '11 and the $3 million that we reported. For the full year, we had almost $49 million compared to $44 million guidance, and that difference was a combination of LIFO and foreign exchange throughout the year.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, one quick one for you, just following up on the Fluid side. You referenced all the traction on the pump front. I was curious what your aftermarket mix is now in this business, particularly as you look out to full year '11 versus where it's been histo
componenttext: Bob, one quick one for you, just following up on the Fluid side. You referenced all the traction on the pump front. I was curious what your aftermarket mix is now in this business, particularly as you look out to full year '11 versus where it's been historically. I was also curious if your delivery tonnage and equipment are beginning to elongate a little bit that now given that demand?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, with lead times, they're pushed out to about 12 months now. We're looking to reel those back with the capacity expansions that we've got in process, which will be going on throughout this year. As it relates to the mix, we're still largely driven b
componenttext: First, with lead times, they're pushed out to about 12 months now. We're looking to reel those back with the capacity expansions that we've got in process, which will be going on throughout this year. As it relates to the mix, we're still largely driven by the whole good pumps as our install base grows. But to your point, the fluid cylinders, the fluid in aftermarket, which is the big component, is going to grow substantially as we get an installed base and the frac intensity continues to increase.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a point of reference that the 12-month delivery time, how does that compare to six months ago?
componenttext: Just a point of reference that the 12-month delivery time, how does that compare to six months ago?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think in the last quarter, when we said we were at little less than 12 months, we were in the eight- to nine-month range, but we're continuing to book orders and build backlog.
componenttext: No, I think in the last quarter, when we said we were at little less than 12 months, we were in the eight- to nine-month range, but we're continuing to book orders and build backlog.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Doug Becker from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Doug Becker from Bank of America.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bill, you mentioned that pricing for production looks better in the second half rather than the first half as you work through backlog? What's the prospect for moving pricing margins higher as orders pick up over the course of the year? And with rising st
componenttext: Bill, you mentioned that pricing for production looks better in the second half rather than the first half as you work through backlog? What's the prospect for moving pricing margins higher as orders pick up over the course of the year? And with rising steel prices, is there more of a risk or an opportunity to margins at this point?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is John. Clearly, Peter pointed out the fundamentals improving in subsea, and that's manifesting itself in the number of major projects over $100 million, which is the list of those projects is clearly larger then what we saw in 2010. We rebuilt our
componenttext: This is John. Clearly, Peter pointed out the fundamentals improving in subsea, and that's manifesting itself in the number of major projects over $100 million, which is the list of those projects is clearly larger then what we saw in 2010. We rebuilt our backlog in 2010. The other subsea suppliers can be expected to do the same in 2011. And I would think, like Bill said, towards the back end to 2011, we would expect pricing to improve as the tendering activity increases and everybody starts rebuilding their backlog. So that's what we would see in subsea pricing start to improve towards the end of this year. Now on the cost side, nickel prices have gone up and nickels are an important component on our subsea equipment. Steel prices have gone up near term, but they're actually expected to be flat for the year as the construction industry being down had a negative impact on steel. So we don't see big increases in steel prices for the full year. We have seen increase the nickel, but we've been able to lock in nickel prices last year for most of this year. So we don't see a real big impact, at least in the near term, on raw material prices. At least the price increases that we'll see, we think we can mitigate.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

componenttext: Peter, just a quick one. How close did you take a look at the Wood group well support assets?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, you mentioned the lead time on the pumps extending out to 12 months now, but you'd also made a comment earlier about the challenges of managing the supply chain. Is the lead time extension entirely your own capacity bottlenecks? Or are there some iss
componenttext: Bob, you mentioned the lead time on the pumps extending out to 12 months now, but you'd also made a comment earlier about the challenges of managing the supply chain. Is the lead time extension entirely your own capacity bottlenecks? Or are there some issues upstream with you?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a combination of everything. Obviously, your boxes, thing like that, the lead times are going out. So it's a combination of both internal capacity and supply chain.
componenttext: Yes, it's a combination of everything. Obviously, your boxes, thing like that, the lead times are going out. So it's a combination of both internal capacity and supply chain.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: So can you help us just understand a little bit better. As you expand your capacity, are there also kind of parallel initiatives going on that make you comfortable you'll be able to exploit that capacity expansion?
componenttext: So can you help us just understand a little bit better. As you expand your capacity, are there also kind of parallel initiatives going on that make you comfortable you'll be able to exploit that capacity expansion?

componenttextpreview: Yes, we're qualifying alternative suppliers on a global basis to support our expected demand.
componenttext: Yes, we're qualifying alternative suppliers on a global basis to support our expected demand.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And with this extending lead times, are you able to A, raise prices efficiently to compensate for cost increases? Or B, raise prices more than what's necessary? Can you expand margins in this environment?
componenttext: And with this extending lead times, are you able to A, raise prices efficiently to compensate for cost increases? Or B, raise prices more than what's necessary? Can you expand margins in this environment?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, so far, as I mentioned earlier, our focus has been to raise prices to maintain margins, and it's still pretty competitive out there, despite the fact that the market is as strong as it is. So again, it's something we keep a constant eye on.
componenttext: Well, so far, as I mentioned earlier, our focus has been to raise prices to maintain margins, and it's still pretty competitive out there, despite the fact that the market is as strong as it is. So again, it's something we keep a constant eye on.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And on the treating iron side of the business, I don't know if you have the ability to tell this, but are you aware that the treating iron is wearing out significantly faster than it did, say, a couple of years ago?
componenttext: And on the treating iron side of the business, I don't know if you have the ability to tell this, but are you aware that the treating iron is wearing out significantly faster than it did, say, a couple of years ago?

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a fair comment, and I think as what Bill mentioned that we expected it to grow in consistent rig count, which by the way is a historic pattern of Fluid Control, has been for years. But the frac intensity does add a new dimension to that. So re
componenttext: Yes, that's a fair comment, and I think as what Bill mentioned that we expected it to grow in consistent rig count, which by the way is a historic pattern of Fluid Control, has been for years. But the frac intensity does add a new dimension to that. So really, again, our growth's going to come from whatever incremental increases we have in rig count plus frac intensity increases, which, by the way, just didn't start happening this year. That's something we began to see last year coupled with our continued penetration of Well Service Pump market share and additional scope like manifold trailers.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: It varies by project, but our strategy is to continue to try to do more and more things on the seabed, expand our product offering, our technology base. So it's been a core strategy. You can remember when we started out, we were $8 or $9 a tree, and now l
componenttext: It varies by project, but our strategy is to continue to try to do more and more things on the seabed, expand our product offering, our technology base. So it's been a core strategy. You can remember when we started out, we were $8 or $9 a tree, and now last year, I think last couple of years, we've been over in the low 20s. And that depends on the mix, but obviously, it's been a wonderful thing for us to be able to execute this strategy and adding more and more to the kit on the seabed.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statements issued yesterday can be found on our website. I would like to caution you with respect to any forwar
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statements issued yesterday can be found on our website. I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-looking statements made during this call. Although these forward-looking statements are based on our current views and assumptions regarding future events, future business conditions and the outlook for us based on currently available information, these forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by these statements. I refer you to our disclosures regarding risk factors in our SEC filings.
I will now turn the call over to Peter Kinnear, FMC Technologies Chairman and CEO.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2010 conference call. With me today are Bill Schumann, our CFO; John Gremp, our President and COO; and Bob Potter, our Executive Vice President. First, I will share with you some highlights from the quarter and
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2010 conference call. With me today are Bill Schumann, our CFO; John Gremp, our President and COO; and Bob Potter, our Executive Vice President. First, I will share with you some highlights from the quarter and the year. Bill will then provide you with the details on our financial performance and our outlook for 2011. Finally, we'll open up the call for your questions.
I'm pleased to say we had another strong quarter and finished the year with record results. Our fourth quarter earnings per share were $0.82, including a benefit of $0.13 from some tax items. We earned $3.06 for the full year. Our full year EPS was another all-time high and represented our eighth consecutive year of earnings growth since our IPO. 
In the quarter, the total company backlog rose 14% to $4.2 billion. This increase was led by $1.1 billion in subsea orders, including orders for 39 subsea trees. For 2010, our total company backlog increased 64%. This was the first full year increase since 2007. Our subsea backlog grew for the fourth consecutive quarter and now stands at $3.6 billion after starting the year at $2.0 billion. Our 2010 subsea inbound of $4.1 billion was a record for that business. 
It was driven by solid fundamentals in the deepwater market, such as favorable oil prices, rig fleet expansion, capital spending increases and international growth. The price of oil remained at a level that has been conducive to Deepwater economics. This strength in the oil prices continued into 2011 and does not appear to be showing any signs of weakness.
Expansion of the deepwater rig fleet is a critical enabler for our customers to expand our capacity to complete more subsea wells. After growing 27% since 2007, the fleet is expected to grow another 20% over the next two years. The reported 2011 capital spending estimates for the major oil companies shows an increase of almost 20%, driven in large part by deepwater activity. Typically, the actual capital spending exceeds these early industry estimates.
The deepwater market continues to grow internationally. In 2010, we received orders for projects offshore: Brazil, Nigeria, Angola, Russia, China and Norway. In 2011, we have potential subsea awards in all those locations, and in addition, there are other growth areas, such as Australia where we expect some long-awaited offshore gas projects to be awarded. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, we've been executing our pre-moratorium backlog and have received a few new post-Macondo orders. However, the basin will remain a risk for us until the permitting issues a resolve. The Gulf of Mexico was approximately 11% of our total revenue in 2010, and we expect that it will be an even lower percentage in 2011. Fortunately for us, the Gulf of Mexico region is being largely offset by the combined continued strength that I just mentioned in the large growing international markets. 
Overall, we believe the subsea market will remain robust. As we have suggested last quarter, we think that our 2011 subsea orders could equal the record we set in 2010. Our confidence is based on the market fundamentals, our strong customer alliances and on our technology leadership in areas like subsea processing.
Turning to our Surface Wellhead business, we had a strong fourth quarter for orders and sales. In fact, our Surface Wellhead orders in the fourth quarter were at the highest level since before the industry downturn. 
Shifting to our Energy Processing businesses, the ongoing strength in the North American land rig count combined with the associated pressure pumping activity in both liquids and gas shale plays continue to drive growth in our Fluid Control business. In fact, we had record Fluid Control revenue in the quarter and its backlog reached another all-time high. Our Fluid Control business has recovered substantially since the downturn in the industry. Sales in 2010 for Fluid Control were up 70% from 2009 and orders more than doubled. 
One of the key factors has been the successful market penetration of our Well Service Pump. After receiving almost no pump orders during the 2009 industry downturn, we booked record pump orders in 2010, and the near-term outlook for these pumps and other Fluid Control products remains very positive.
As for the other Energy Processing businesses, each one had sequential order growth in the fourth quarter, and we expect full year order growth in all these businesses for 2011. 
So let me just say in summary, we had a record year for earnings in subsea orders. The market fundamentals for Deepwater continue to be very, very positive for subsea, and we experienced record performance from our Fluid Control business. So let me now turn the call over to Bill Schumann.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Peter. Energy Production sales for the fourth quarter were $875 million, down 11% from last year but up 14% sequentially. The decrease from the prior year was mainly driven by a mix of early-stage subsea projects in our backlog relative to a year
componenttext:
Thanks, Peter. Energy Production sales for the fourth quarter were $875 million, down 11% from last year but up 14% sequentially. The decrease from the prior year was mainly driven by a mix of early-stage subsea projects in our backlog relative to a year ago. In contrast, the sequential increase is an indication that the rate of execution on subsea projects and backlog is increasing. 
Energy Production generated operating profit of $105 million in the quarter, down 20% from the prior year quarter, mainly due to lower subsea volume. Margins were 12% in the quarter and just under 15% for the full year. For 2011, we expect that the margin to be in the range of 12% to 13% with some fluctuation from quarter-to-quarter depending on timing and the effectiveness of our project execution. 
Inbound orders in Energy Production were $1.3 billion in the quarter, including subsea orders of $1.1 billion. This profit total subsea order amount for the year to a record $4.1 billion. We ended the year with a backlog of $3.9 billion dollars, including subsea backlog of $3.6 billion. Not included in these amounts were the recently announced Total GirRI, Statoil, Gygrid [indiscernible] 21:22) awards, which will all be booked in the first quarter of 2011.
Turning to Energy Processing. Sales were $223 million, up 26% from the year-ago quarter. The increase was driven by our Fluid Control business led by our WECO/Chiksan flowline Products and our Well Service Pumps as Peter described. Their sales together set a record due to continued strength of the North American pressure pumping activity. While the other Energy Processing businesses had lower sales in the quarter compared to last year, they were up 18% from the third quarter and all of them contributed to that increase. 
Energy Processing generated record operating profit of $43 million, more than double the prior year quarter. The increase was primarily the result of our record volume in Fluid Control. The fourth quarter margin of 19.5% was also a new record. In 2011, we expect the full year margin for the segment to be in a range of 17% to 18%. I would caution, however, that our Fluid Control business is subject to the volatility of the North American lane rig count and the pressure pumping market, and that can drive significant changes in this segment margin. 
Total inbound orders for Energy Processing reached an all-time high of $256 million, up 48% from last year's fourth quarter. The improvement was again driven by Fluid Control but was aided by order strength in Measurement Solutions also. Backlog ended the quarter at $296 million.
Now for the corporate items. Corporate expense in the quarter was $10.9 million. Other expense net was $3 million. This was less than we had anticipated due mainly to lower LIFO expenses. Our fourth quarter tax rate of 24.7% was impacted by a number of items that we don't expect to repeat at least with the same impact as we experienced in the past quarter:  The quarter included the resolution of an IRS tax appeal as previously announced; other changes in reserves for uncertain tax positions; actions we took in the quarter related to changes in U.S. tax law that increased our tax expense; and the late receipt of confirmation for a tax incentive that we had anticipated receiving before year end. Removing these items from EPS would reduce earnings per share by $0.13 to $0.69 for the quarter.
Adjusting for these items still leaves us with a 36.3% tax rate in the quarter, which was still higher than anticipated due to the higher U.S. taxes on undistributed foreign earnings. For the full year 2010, the tax rate was 32.7% after adjusting for those special items. We did receive the letter of confirmation for the tax incentives in January. It is retroactive to 2009 but the tax benefit will be recorded in the first quarter of 2011. Our guidance for 2011 tax rate is at an annual rate of 30% to 32%, which excludes the first quarter tax incentive benefit of $7 million.
We ramped up our capital spending this quarter to $47 million, bringing the full year capital spending to $112 million. This ramp up will continue into to this year as we expect capital spending in 2011 to be in excess of $200 million. Facility improvements planned for Brazil and Asia make up a large portion of this increase, along with the expansion of our Fluid Control facilities in North America. 
At the end of the quarter, we had net debt position of $48 million. This was comprised of $315 million of cash and $363 million of debt. We averaged $121.7 million diluted shares outstanding in the quarter due to a combination of the ramp up in capital spending, an increase in pension funding and a desire to keep our net debt near the current level, we did not repurchase any shares in the quarter.
Turning to the overall outlook for 2011. We expect another strong year in subsea orders. As Peter mentioned, we could potentially reach the same record amount of orders as 2010, driving our subsea backlog to a record level. However, the situation in the Gulf presents a risk to that level of orders. On the top line, we expect improvement in all of our businesses even in Fluid Control, where we're coming off a record year in sales. 
Subsea and Surface Wellhead sales could also reach all-time highs. The Measurement Solutions and loading system sales will rebound and start to approach the levels they saw in 2008. The 2011 margins in production will be in a range of 12% to 13%. In Processing, the 2011 margins will be in line with the 2010 average of 17% to 18%. And again, for earnings, our 2011 guidance for diluted EPS is $3.20 to $3.40 per share. Operator, you may now open up the call for questions.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on a couple of your guide points here on the margin front. Energy Processing 17% to 18% coming off a 19.5% fourth quarter run rate. Can you give us some insight as to now the ramp down in margins that you expect in 2011?
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on a couple of your guide points here on the margin front. Energy Processing 17% to 18% coming off a 19.5% fourth quarter run rate. Can you give us some insight as to now the ramp down in margins that you expect in 2011?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kurt. We mentioned that was a record quarter for us in terms of margins, and really what happened was Fluid Control had a strong quarter, actually a little bit stronger than the third quarter even, but the real differential here was the other busines
componenttext: Yes, Kurt. We mentioned that was a record quarter for us in terms of margins, and really what happened was Fluid Control had a strong quarter, actually a little bit stronger than the third quarter even, but the real differential here was the other businesses. Measurement and Loading Systems had an outstanding fourth quarter, and while we expect them to improve their full year performance in 2011, it's not going to be as strong as their fourth quarter performance. So we anticipate that the Fluid business in 2011 will grow kind of in line with the rig count, and that the Loading and Measurement will improve their performance actually probably at the top line a little bit better than our Fluid Control business, and that will kind of dilute the margins a little bit. But in absolute terms, we're going to deliver increased earnings in the Energy Processing business in 2011.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing any slowdown whatsoever in the Frac Equipment business, any indications that the service companies feel there's enough capacity in the market at this point and are starting to ramp down their spend?
componenttext: Are you seeing any slowdown whatsoever in the Frac Equipment business, any indications that the service companies feel there's enough capacity in the market at this point and are starting to ramp down their spend?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kurt, Bob Potter. No, we continue to see a robust environment for the Frac Equipment, and obviously, there's a couple of really important reasons for that. One is rig count, which so far this year is averaging about 11% above the average for last year, an
componenttext: Kurt, Bob Potter. No, we continue to see a robust environment for the Frac Equipment, and obviously, there's a couple of really important reasons for that. One is rig count, which so far this year is averaging about 11% above the average for last year, and we're kind of expecting a similar number through the rest of the year in our guidance. And secondly, the frac intensity continues to increase. These operators have learned that there's not much incremental cost to additional frac stages longer laterals, and so kind of separated from rig count, we have the frac intensity increases, which are driving a lot of improvement in Fluid Control business as well.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the other follow up I had on Energy Production margins, the indication of 12% to 13% range for '11 would imply that you think the fourth quarter was then your low point for margins in Energy Production. I just wonder if you could give us some insights
componenttext: And the other follow up I had on Energy Production margins, the indication of 12% to 13% range for '11 would imply that you think the fourth quarter was then your low point for margins in Energy Production. I just wonder if you could give us some insights as to your degree of confidence and how you drive that confidence into, say, the fourth quarter being your low point?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Kurt, as we've laid out our budget and our plans, there really isn't a quarter that sticks out as an obvious trough in margins. That being said, the second half of 2011 looks better than the first half. So I guess I'm not ready to call a quarter for
componenttext: Well, Kurt, as we've laid out our budget and our plans, there really isn't a quarter that sticks out as an obvious trough in margins. That being said, the second half of 2011 looks better than the first half. So I guess I'm not ready to call a quarter for the trough.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
