componenttext: Okay. I think on your last call, you had mentioned that Petrobras is already contemplating incremental orders for Marlim. Is there any change to the thinking there?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, they're very excited about their technology. They're anxious to get it in the water and the potential for this technology is significant for the many fields that Petrobras has. So yes, it's clearly, their expectation that they'll apply this tec
componenttext: Well, yes, they're very excited about their technology. They're anxious to get it in the water and the potential for this technology is significant for the many fields that Petrobras has. So yes, it's clearly, their expectation that they'll apply this technology in many more wells.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's actually Justin sitting in for Kurt. I just wanted to follow up on Energy Processing. The orders in the quarter, $340 million, were very strong given the constraints from a manufacturing standpoint. So were there orders booked in the quarter ahead of
componenttext: It's actually Justin sitting in for Kurt. I just wanted to follow up on Energy Processing. The orders in the quarter, $340 million, were very strong given the constraints from a manufacturing standpoint. So were there orders booked in the quarter ahead of new capacity coming online? Or should we be looking at when new capacity comes online, you should see a ramp in the orders? And then kind of a follow-on to that is has the lead time at all changed between when orders are booked and revenues recognized in Energy Processing?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Justin, this is Bob. Well, first of all, on the lead time question, we're starting to see lead times shorten some as we bring new capacity online. In fact, I think it hasn't been that long ago, we were talking about having sold out most of 2012. Now we're
componenttext: Justin, this is Bob. Well, first of all, on the lead time question, we're starting to see lead times shorten some as we bring new capacity online. In fact, I think it hasn't been that long ago, we were talking about having sold out most of 2012. Now we're going to enter 2012 with about 40% of the capacity for Well Service Pumps in backlog. So we've begun to extend the capacity like we had intended, and therefore, lead times are shortening somewhat. As far as the order rate is concerned, the service companies haven't yet begun to book their 2012 CapEx plans, but they're close. We expect to see some of the demand for 2012 released by the major service companies later in the third quarter, early fourth quarter.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And then if I could just expand a little bit more on the prior questions around subsea processing. If we're looking at 7 potential projects for 2012, can you guys elaborate a little bit more on what the mix has been in the past between, out
componenttext: Got it, okay. And then if I could just expand a little bit more on the prior questions around subsea processing. If we're looking at 7 potential projects for 2012, can you guys elaborate a little bit more on what the mix has been in the past between, out of total subsea processing has contributed, which percentage and how you would expect that to maybe change going forward if processing continues to pick up at this rate?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we've given those numbers in the past, but to maybe help frame it for you. If you go back 5 years, there was probably 1 subsea processing project every other year. And the average revenue from a subsea processing project is maybe aroun
componenttext: Well, I don't think we've given those numbers in the past, but to maybe help frame it for you. If you go back 5 years, there was probably 1 subsea processing project every other year. And the average revenue from a subsea processing project is maybe around $100 million. And then if you look at the last couple of years, we've averaged 2, 3, maybe even 4 as they kind of clump together in a particular calendar year, subsea processing projects. So that gets you up to maybe $200 million to $400 million of inbound for the entire industry, and although that's mostly been us. And then you look forward, and now I'm saying there 7 named projects in 2012. They probably won't all happen, they typically move around a lot. But you can get a sense then of how we're going from $100 million every other year to $200 million to $400 million the last couple of years to something much larger than that going forward as the industry adopts this new technology.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Uhlmer with GHS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Uhlmer with GHS.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to kind of hone in a little bit on kind of how you're turning your backlog over. Presumably as you call off awards that you generated in the quarter, do those turn a little bit quicker so that we can see a return to turning it over 25% to 30% of
componenttext: I wanted to kind of hone in a little bit on kind of how you're turning your backlog over. Presumably as you call off awards that you generated in the quarter, do those turn a little bit quicker so that we can see a return to turning it over 25% to 30% of your backlog at any given quarter.  As you've trended down this past quarter in both segments, I'm trying to get a handle on how to roll through revenues. Can you help me out with that?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, how we converted the backlog. That's complicated because it varies by project and so forth. But you're on the right track, Brian. If they're are call-offs, they're typically coming from partners, they're coming from where we're already
componenttext: Well, first of all, how we converted the backlog. That's complicated because it varies by project and so forth. But you're on the right track, Brian. If they're are call-offs, they're typically coming from partners, they're coming from where we're already the incumbent, the designs are done. Maybe we're even using our standard designs for some of these call-offs. So the lead time for the conversion from inbound is going to be much shorter. If you take a major EPC contract that includes trees, manifolds, all the infrastructure, which is designed to order, you're talking about a much longer period of time. And conversion is going to be spread over a long period of time, and it won't be even. We've talked about this before, that in the early cycle of a major subsea project, we're mostly doing engineering. And based on our percent complete processed, we're not going to convert a lot in the early cycle. But when that raw material and those expensive components start arriving, then we start moving real quickly up to the conversion curve. And then at the very end while we're doing testing, it starts to slow down again. So that varies by major project, it's a little hard to predict, but you're on the right track. If they're small orders that are call-offs, they're likely to be converted faster than a major EPC project.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we could presumably see a decent jump in 3Q and then maybe flatten out for a couple of quarters before we have a big ramp in the back half of '12 based on your ordering flows?
componenttext: So we could presumably see a decent jump in 3Q and then maybe flatten out for a couple of quarters before we have a big ramp in the back half of '12 based on your ordering flows?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think for the second half of this -- I'll let Bill comment on this, but the second half of 2011 is driven more by the large projects that we inbounded in 2010 than the shorter-cycle projects that we booked more recently.
componenttext: Well, I think for the second half of this -- I'll let Bill comment on this, but the second half of 2011 is driven more by the large projects that we inbounded in 2010 than the shorter-cycle projects that we booked more recently.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, to hit our -- we did almost $1.5 billion in the first half in subsea. And we've got to do about $900 million a quarter in the second half. And we did $795 million in the second quarter. So we think we're on track to get there. But it is a sig
componenttext: Yes, I mean, to hit our -- we did almost $1.5 billion in the first half in subsea. And we've got to do about $900 million a quarter in the second half. And we did $795 million in the second quarter. So we think we're on track to get there. But it is a significant increase quarter-over-quarter. We haven't or I haven't been privy to laying out the schedule for 2012, so I don't know what it's going to look like exactly in terms of conversion. But 2011, we think it's going to be a little bit higher each quarter.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then rolling into processing, similar obviously backlogs building there. So with the new capacity will start to get the higher percentage churn in 3Q slightly and then back to a more normalized level for your historics in 4Q and on?
componenttext: Okay. And then rolling into processing, similar obviously backlogs building there. So with the new capacity will start to get the higher percentage churn in 3Q slightly and then back to a more normalized level for your historics in 4Q and on?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in processing, we've got some mix issues. The Well Service Pump is 9 to 12 months in terms of inbound to delivery. Flowline is sometimes 2 weeks, sometimes a month. And then some of the other processing businesses like loading systems have longer le
componenttext: Well, in processing, we've got some mix issues. The Well Service Pump is 9 to 12 months in terms of inbound to delivery. Flowline is sometimes 2 weeks, sometimes a month. And then some of the other processing businesses like loading systems have longer lead time conversions. So I think in general, with the growth of the Flowline Product lines and the quick conversions, you're going to see generally faster turns of backlog in Energy Processing. But it's a little tricky because of the different businesses that are in that segment.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And my second question should be a simple one. In general, I know you don't want to get into your frame agreements in too specific details. But in general, are your margins higher for your frame agreements and call-off awards than they
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And my second question should be a simple one. In general, I know you don't want to get into your frame agreements in too specific details. But in general, are your margins higher for your frame agreements and call-off awards than they are for the mega projects, and is there an order of magnitude or is it fairly close?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the whole pricing environment, Brian, is different because we're coming out of a down cycle and people are rebuilding their backlogs. When you have a big large tender that's being competitively bid and with multiple suppliers as they try to rebuild
componenttext: Well, the whole pricing environment, Brian, is different because we're coming out of a down cycle and people are rebuilding their backlogs. When you have a big large tender that's being competitively bid and with multiple suppliers as they try to rebuild their backlog then you're going to have competitive pricing intensity associated with that very large award. And so in that situation, then the frame agreements, which are negotiated awards, are probably going to be, the margins are probably going to be a little more favorable. The other thing is usually our frame agreements are based on standardization, a lot of repeatability. Our cost position is a lot better and again, the margins are probably a little bit better for that reason. Now obviously as the market moves in a different direction, then the tendered projects would probably improve in pricing and might start to look more similar to a frame agreement negotiated price. So it kind of depends on the market environment. Right now, we're coming out of the downturn, so I'd say the frame agreement numbers are better and may approach more equal to tendered projects, particularly in 2012 when we definitely expect pricing to improve as all these awards get made in 2012.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Kevin Simpson with Miller Tabak.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Kevin Simpson with Miller Tabak.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2 questions. One, maybe first for Bill. Are you likely to report kind of a back-end loaded second half or more a 4Q that would be more like you used to show materially above the 3Q, say, several years ago? Or is it going to be more smooth ramp up
componenttext: I guess, 2 questions. One, maybe first for Bill. Are you likely to report kind of a back-end loaded second half or more a 4Q that would be more like you used to show materially above the 3Q, say, several years ago? Or is it going to be more smooth ramp up?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, historically, we've always had a big fourth quarter that used to be driven by Fluid Control and subsea. For whatever reason, subsea always had a big fourth quarter. I think the logic on the big fourth quarter for subsea is reflected in our accountin
componenttext: Well, historically, we've always had a big fourth quarter that used to be driven by Fluid Control and subsea. For whatever reason, subsea always had a big fourth quarter. I think the logic on the big fourth quarter for subsea is reflected in our accounting and the fact that our suppliers want to deliver the product to us in their calendar year. And if they deliver inventory to us, we recorded the cost and then include it as progress on our contracts and consequently recognize revenue. And I don't think this year is going to be any different from that. I would expect subsea, which is now a larger part of the total to have a big fourth quarter, and that would drive the whole company to have a big fourth quarter. The flowline business, I think, because of the growth of it, I'm not confident that the fourth quarter is going to be much different than the third quarter. We're kind of flat out, and our customers are pretty flat out, I think, in that business. But I think it'll be driven by subsea, and I think you're right, fourth quarter will be larger than the third quarter.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And processing to some degree, Fluid Control function of adding -- capacity adds as such that you're bring them on.
componenttext: And processing to some degree, Fluid Control function of adding -- capacity adds as such that you're bring them on.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's not -- I don't think we're going to see much of it. Actually, Bob alluded to this, but we're also expanding the flowline capacity. We may see more flowline capacity come on than well service pump capacity by year end. So we could see a little th
componenttext: Yes, it's not -- I don't think we're going to see much of it. Actually, Bob alluded to this, but we're also expanding the flowline capacity. We may see more flowline capacity come on than well service pump capacity by year end. So we could see a little there, but we'll see some of that in the third quarter, too.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and John, the margins in the inbound for 2Q and maybe -- is the trend somewhat towards improvement versus say 1Q or even more important, I guess, from what you booked last year? Or is it hard to tell with the mix that's coming in?
componenttext: Okay, and John, the margins in the inbound for 2Q and maybe -- is the trend somewhat towards improvement versus say 1Q or even more important, I guess, from what you booked last year? Or is it hard to tell with the mix that's coming in?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the margins that we booked in the second quarter were mostly driven, as I said earlier, by our frame agreement, so they looked more like Q1, which, as Bill pointed out, were at our expectations. I think that where we're really going to see the margi
componenttext: Well, the margins that we booked in the second quarter were mostly driven, as I said earlier, by our frame agreement, so they looked more like Q1, which, as Bill pointed out, were at our expectations. I think that where we're really going to see the margin change and the pricing change is on some of these very, very large projects that are in the process of being tendered. That's what we need to watch as those get awarded, what's the pricing level of those. So the margins that we put in backlog in the second quarter looked a lot like Q1, and that was driven by our negotiated prices with our frame agreement partners.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other kind of follow-up. Beyond the big name projects that are going to go on either side of year end, I guess, you sound pretty bullish on next year, in general, on order flow after what's going to be another big year this year and a b
componenttext: Okay. And then one other kind of follow-up. Beyond the big name projects that are going to go on either side of year end, I guess, you sound pretty bullish on next year, in general, on order flow after what's going to be another big year this year and a big year last year. Are you, John, assuming that later next year, you get more -- I guess, 2 markets, pre-salt type orders from Petrobras or the other being finally some a step up in Nigeria business, which I guess has lagged for political reasons?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're right. When you look at 2012, one of the reasons it'll make it such a strong year for subsea awards for the industry is that the expectation that there will be some big numbers for Brazil. As you know, Brazil had their multiyear contr
componenttext: Well, I think you're right. When you look at 2012, one of the reasons it'll make it such a strong year for subsea awards for the industry is that the expectation that there will be some big numbers for Brazil. As you know, Brazil had their multiyear contracts for their conventional equipment in 2010. We believe that it's time now for Petrobras to award some more trees for pre-salt. We've heard from Petrobras that they're considering more multiyear contracts, aggregating the requirements for both conventional and pre-salt. The numbers that we're hearing about are very large so the combination of Petrobras needing to get some more trees on order for pre-salt and this conversation about aggregating the requirements in multiyear contracts, if that were to get achieved in 2012, that would certainly contribute to 2012 being a very strong year. And then the same is true with Nigeria. We know we've got a big project in Ghana [ph], Erha and so forth. And these projects, which again are largely absent in 2010 and '11 would show up in 2012. And they would contribute to the strong 2012 numbers. So you're right. I think between Brazil and Nigeria, and even some more projects in Angola, for that matter, would definitely contribute to the strong 2012 versus 2011.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Collin Gerry with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Collin Gerry with Raymond James.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Most of mine have been answered. I guess I'm going to beat the dead horse here on margins a little bit. If I just do the arithmetic, it sounds to me like that the 11.5% to 12.5% guidance for the production side implies kind of a back half exit rate in the
componenttext: Most of mine have been answered. I guess I'm going to beat the dead horse here on margins a little bit. If I just do the arithmetic, it sounds to me like that the 11.5% to 12.5% guidance for the production side implies kind of a back half exit rate in the 13% to 14.5% range, so obviously a pretty big bounce from where we are. I guess, just 2 questions are mechanical or practically, are the big changes mix or kind of the pick up off the bottom like in the surface side that you mentioned? And also what is the big difference between the bottom and -- the low end and the high end of that in terms of achieving those?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is John. The difference between the high end and the low end is going to come for Energy Production is going to come from execution. We've got the backlog. We need to convert it, the pace at which we convert it, converting it without execution issues
componenttext: This is John. The difference between the high end and the low end is going to come for Energy Production is going to come from execution. We've got the backlog. We need to convert it, the pace at which we convert it, converting it without execution issues and higher costs, which are going to drive the margin, and that includes surface. Because surface, our international business in surface is also a longer-cycle business.  They have the revenue and backlog. They just need to convert it, and we need to convert it without execution issues. That'll be the difference between the ranges on Energy Production.

componenttext: Okay. So just a little bit more on the surface side. I want to ask in terms of these execution issues, maybe we could get some more specifics in terms of what maybe -- you didn't want to call them onetime costs, but maybe what those were. And kind of what were the execution issues? Was it supply chain-related issues? Was it staffing? Maybe just a little bit more granularity there if possible.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think Bill talked about the 2 big issues. First of all, it was the lack of orders in the first half of the year, internationally, which really caused us some absorption projects in the international locations. And then secondly and not to be under
componenttext: Well, I think Bill talked about the 2 big issues. First of all, it was the lack of orders in the first half of the year, internationally, which really caused us some absorption projects in the international locations. And then secondly and not to be underestimated is the investment we're making in North America to fuel the growth. I mean, Bill talked about new facilities. He talked about training. He didn't touch on the number of people we're hiring. We're adding significant numbers of people to our service training and apprentice programs, all of which are designed to support the growth that we expect to continue to see in North America. Those are the big items.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think a couple of us have been dancing around the question, but I thought I'd ask it just directly. Does anything that's happened in the second quarter in the subsea business presumably, or for that matter, I guess, Surface can contribute, but is it imp
componenttext: I think a couple of us have been dancing around the question, but I thought I'd ask it just directly. Does anything that's happened in the second quarter in the subsea business presumably, or for that matter, I guess, Surface can contribute, but is it impacting your initial thoughts about where 2012 margins in Production Systems may be headed?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, not at all. I think, as I said, when you look at 2012, it's going to be a very strong year for subsea awards. And we fully expect pricing to improve. The timing on whether it improves, obviously, is tricky to predict. But we see pricing improving in 2
componenttext: No, not at all. I think, as I said, when you look at 2012, it's going to be a very strong year for subsea awards. And we fully expect pricing to improve. The timing on whether it improves, obviously, is tricky to predict. But we see pricing improving in 2012 after the initial tranche of major awards are made, which would improve margins. I think, on the subsea side, where our ability to execute is getting better and better, and because we have the backlog, our organization is intact. It's prepared for the growth. And I'm very confident that our execution in subsea will only improve, plus we have the advantage because we'll be going in 2012 presumably with higher backlog. We'll be in a position to convert that backlog at revenue levels that should allow us more leverage in 2012 than what we saw in 2011, and that'll contribute to better margins. On the surface side, I think, as we pointed out, a lot of it is timing. We've now got the awards and backlog and we'll be converting that. And the execution, which have delayed some shipments and increased cost, those are largely going to be behind us in the second half of this year. So no, I think 2012 is set up for good execution and not a continuation of what we had experienced this year.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me ask the question a little bit differently, if I may, John. I think there was a line of argument that said that in 2011, much of the work you were going to recognize was based on frame agreements or your partners, and therefore might be of a h
componenttext: Okay. Let me ask the question a little bit differently, if I may, John. I think there was a line of argument that said that in 2011, much of the work you were going to recognize was based on frame agreements or your partners, and therefore might be of a higher margin, whereas in 2012, it may have been based to a greater degree on more competitively bid work, which as you mentioned earlier in the current environment could have come at more price competitive and thus a lower margin. So there, I think, were some concern that you might have a negative mix in your subsea business, which could push margins lower next year. I don't really hear that in your comments today, but I guess, can you be explicit? Is that an incorrect line of thinking?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is incorrect for couple of reasons. One is the business and the number of frame agreements we have, it keeps increasing. And in 2012, as the industry awards grow, they will be with our partners. And so we'd expect our growth in 2012 and our market
componenttext: Yes, it is incorrect for couple of reasons. One is the business and the number of frame agreements we have, it keeps increasing. And in 2012, as the industry awards grow, they will be with our partners. And so we'd expect our growth in 2012 and our market share in this strong 2012 environment to reflect what it's reflected in the past, and that is good share driven by our frame agreement and frame agreement partners, not necessarily being successful on these competitively intense major projects that are out there. The good thing about having our backlog rebuilt, we can sort of navigate through this period of these first major awards being issued in a strategic and selective fashion in an effort to keep our margins where we want them to be. So no, I'm very confident in 2012, even as the market grows and some of these major projects that are tendered, we're in an extremely good position to navigate through that for the purpose of maintaining and improving our margins.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011

componenttext: Very helpful. I'll follow on one more if you'll indulge me. So if we, for modeling purposes, then thought about 2012 subsea margins relative to the second half of 2011, are you suggesting that they might be stronger than even the second half of '11 margins?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, it's all going to depend on the mix that's in backlog. And so we've got to see what we win and what we don't win. And we've got to see how the market responds, particularly in this initial period when these major awards are let. We haven't seen a lot
componenttext: No, it's all going to depend on the mix that's in backlog. And so we've got to see what we win and what we don't win. And we've got to see how the market responds, particularly in this initial period when these major awards are let. We haven't seen a lot of the pricing yet, so we don't know how just competitively intense it'll be. And the projects margins that we put in backlog and what their margins are really have yet to be seen. Do I believe that we'll have more leverage in 2012 than 2011 because we are growing [ph]? Yes, but beyond that, I think that we need to see that the complexion of our backlog going into 2012 before we comment on margins.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jamal. Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies' Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statements issued yesterday can be found on our website. I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-l

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter 2011 conference call. With me today are Bill Schumann, our CFO; and Bob Potter, our Executive Vice President. I'll share with you some highlights from the quarter, Bill will provide specifics on our financial
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter 2011 conference call. With me today are Bill Schumann, our CFO; and Bob Potter, our Executive Vice President. I'll share with you some highlights from the quarter, Bill will provide specifics on our financial performance and expectations for the remainder of the year and then we'll open up the call for your questions. First, the results for the quarter.
Earnings were $0.50 per diluted share. We recorded $1.3 billion in orders during the third quarter of which $731 million or for subsea systems and included 31 subsea trees. Subsea backlog now stands at $3.8 billion.
For the quarter, total company revenue was $1.2 billion and subsea revenue for the quarter was $824 million. Subsea sales increased 33% over last year and 4% sequentially. While this volume was a record, it was below our expectations. Margins were also both our expectations due to volume and execution. We continue to expect our subsea sales will reach $3.3 billion for the full year as our fourth quarter subsea revenue should approach $1 billion. This expectation is consistent with the fourth quarter, typically being our strongest of the year.
Surface Wellhead revenue was up 16% from the third quarter of 2010, driven largely by North American activity. We're starting to see some of the international timing and execution issues we've experienced in prior quarters improve and believe results away forward looking to reflect this improvement. While we will be able to fully recover from these issues in 2011, they will possibly impact our 2012 results.
Fluid Control continues to see a record event driven by North America pressure pumping activity as orders for both our WECO/Chiksan full of products and our Well Service Pumps are at unprecedented levels. We continue to expand our capacity in these areas to better serve this market.
Results on our other processing businesses grew sequentially and almost the same rate as our Fluid Control and margins improved. Entering the fourth quarter in 2011, we expect quarterly earnings to be between $0.46 and $0.51 as improved operational results are offset by less favorable corporate items, therefore, increasing our full year earnings guidance image of $1.70 to $1.75 per diluted share.
During the quarter, we saw increased the volatility in the oil and natural gas prices. At the current price levels however, onshore developments remain economically attractive for our customers. Subsea is a long cycle business with operators taking a longer-term view and therefore, remaining committed to their subsea developers. Operators are now in the stage of their tendering process where they typically begin to announce subsea awards.
Usual operator patterns give us confidence that 2012 should be a very strong year for inbound in the subsea industry. We inbounded $731 million subsea orders during the quarter with no orders in excess of $150 million. Our year-to-date subsea inbound is now at $2.6 billion. We continue to believe we will approach $4 billion and subsea orders for the year as we inbound the remaining portion of shells really project along with an expected additional larger order before year end.
We're starting to see improvement in our Gulf of Mexico order activity. It also appears to pace as permitting is improving. During the quarter, 15 new deepwater permits were issued or 70% of the pre-Macondo average. Large operators proceeded with development plans in the Gulf of Mexico and we're now seeing the independence and gain more confidence as well. Deepwater recounts are also trending favorably, approximately 20 deepwater rigs were working in the Gulf of Mexico at the end of the quarter or about 2/3 of the pre-Macondo total. I'd now like to turn to the subsea processing market and discuss the Petrobras Marlim project.
Last week, we delivered the Marlim subsea process systems to Petrobras on schedule following successful qualification testing. Petrobras is now planing to install this pilot project in November. The Marlim project has been a collaborative effort between Petrobras and FMC to design the world's deepest water and oil separation unit. The ability to separate water from oil at the seafloor provides a solution that boost production rates and extended the financial viability of the Marlim field. The longer-term prospects for these types of systems are encouraging as Petrobras has an excess of 70 wells where similar characteristics with this technology could be applied.
Moving to our Fluid Control business. We continue to perform at record levels and believe this should continue. Our industry-leading WECO/Chiksan flowline equipment continues to be in strong demand. The industry reaction to our well service pump has been positive and as our capacity expansion comes on stream, we should be able to further improve our market position.
In summary, our market-leading subsea orders were $731 million in the third quarter and we think we will approach the $4 billion level for the full year. Subsea revenue in the quarter of a $24 million was our largest ever and we expect $3.3 billion for the year. Fluid Control continues to perform at record levels and we're raising our full year guidance to a range of $1.70 to $1.75 per diluted share. Bill will now take you through some of the financial details in the quarter.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Energy Production sales for the third quarter was slightly above $1 billion, an increase of 32% from last year's third quarter and 5% from the second quarter of 2011. Our third quarter subsea sales of $824 million were up from the second qua
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Energy Production sales for the third quarter was slightly above $1 billion, an increase of 32% from last year's third quarter and 5% from the second quarter of 2011. Our third quarter subsea sales of $824 million were up from the second quarter but as John said, below our estimates. We're still optimistic we can deliver our fourth quarter that reaches our target of $3.3 billion for the full year. We're now in the stages of subsea projects to drive large revenue increases.
However, we are facing some headwinds from the impact of the stronger dollar. Surface sales were 16% above the third quarter of 2010 and increased 7% sequentially on the strength of North American activity. The delayed international orders that impacted the first half of 2011 have now been received and we now have backlog to support continued growth. Energy Production generated operating profits of $115 million in the quarter, an increase of 8% from the prior year quarter as sales increased. Sequentially, profit increased 18%. Production margins at 11.3% in the quarter were below our estimates. Subsea profitability improved sequentially but fell short of our expectations.
While we did gain the benefits of leveraging our SG&A spend in the quarter, we suffered some delays in projects and incurred increased project costs as we ramped up subsea volume to record levels. Surface operations profitability improved sequentially but we are not where we expected to be here either. We anticipate further progress in the fourth quarter in both these businesses.
We now expect Energy Production margins to be between 10.5% and 11.5% for the full year with fourth quarter margins coming in around 12%. Inbound orders in Energy Production were $934 million in the quarter, including subsea orders of $731 million. Backlog now stands at $4.1 billion, including subsea backlog of $3.8 billion. Backlog was impacted by approximately $320 million of unfavorable foreign currency translation as the dollar strengthened during the quarter. For the full year, foreign exchange has impacted backlog negatively by only $18 million.
Energy Processing sales were $286 million, up 48% from the prior quarter and 9% from the second quarter. The year-over-year increase was again driven by record sales in our Fluid Control business. Measurement solutions, loading systems and the other Energy Processing businesses also contributed to the year-over-year increase with over 20% growth.
Energy Processing generated operating profit of $61 million in the quarter, the third quarter margin was 21%. We now expect our fourth quarter margins to be around 20%. Total inbound orders for Energy Processing were $332 million, up 71% from last year's third quarter. The increase came from Fluid Control and measurement solutions. Backlog ended the quarter at a record $459 million.
Now for the corporate items. Corporate expense in the quarter was $9.3 million. Other expense and revenue net reflects income of $2.7 million. This amount was more favorable than expected due to foreign currency gains of $6.3 million. The quarter also benefited from reduced unqualified benefit plan expense and a change in earnout consideration related to an acquisition.
Our third quarter tax rate was 27.4%. The lower rate was reflective of changes in the country mix of our income. We should finish the year with a tax rate of approximately 29% in the fourth quarter.
Capital spending this quarter was $84 million primarily directed towards our Energy Production businesses and again for the full year, we expect our capital spending to come in near $250 million. At the end of the quarter, we had a net debt position of $194 million, this was comprised of $306 million of cash and $530 million of debt.
We averaged to 243.3 million diluted shares outstanding during the quarter, and we repurchased 1.5 million shares of stock during the quarter at an average price of approximately $40 per share. We finished the quarter with 3.3 million shares remaining in our share repurchase program.
Looking at the fourth quarter, our EPS guidance is $0.46 to $0.51 per diluted share. Compared to the third quarter, this guidance includes increased surface and subsea sales and improvements in Energy Production margins in addition to some improvements in the Energy Processing segment. In the fourth quarter though, some of these operational improvements will be offset by increased expenses associated with corporate items. Excluding foreign exchange and some of the special adjustments we had in the third quarter, our normal level of other expense and revenue is $8 million to $9 million per quarter.
In the fourth quarter, we expect there will be $10 million or $0.03 per share above this level and this estimate is included in our EPS guidance. Accordingly, we are adjusting our full year 2011 diluted earnings per share guidance to a range of $1.70 to $1.75.
Operator, you may now open up the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: So far, what we've heard from the operators is that the projects that they launched year ago and put in motion, they're not factoring in any of the economic uncertainty in their decisions. They're proceeding I think with confidence on the long-term oil pr
componenttext: So far, what we've heard from the operators is that the projects that they launched year ago and put in motion, they're not factoring in any of the economic uncertainty in their decisions. They're proceeding I think with confidence on the long-term oil price at today's levels supports their developments. So we're not hearing, that does not to say that didn't happen but we're not hearing any concerns the delays in projects and anomalies. These are large complex projects, usually involving or oftentimes involving national oil companies and that's the kind of delay that we're seeing. Nothing about the I've heard anyway about revising their economic models based on economic uncertainty.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And you talked a little bit about the Gulf of Mexico on the outlook You have 20 rigs joining there now Most of them are drilling on development work. Of the 31 tress you got this quarter, were any out the Gulf and can you give us kind of a roadmap a
componenttext: Okay. And you talked a little bit about the Gulf of Mexico on the outlook You have 20 rigs joining there now Most of them are drilling on development work. Of the 31 tress you got this quarter, were any out the Gulf and can you give us kind of a roadmap as how you see that progressing over the next 12 months or mostly onesies and twosies Do you see some big projects there How do you think it's going to develop?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just go to the Gulf for a minute. It is encouraging, The pace of permitting is clearly picking up, We're getting close to Macondo levels, The rig levels, The next probably at the current rate by the middle of next year, we'll be at pre-Macondo
componenttext: Yes. Let me just go to the Gulf for a minute. It is encouraging, The pace of permitting is clearly picking up, We're getting close to Macondo levels, The rig levels, The next probably at the current rate by the middle of next year, we'll be at pre-Macondo levels, I think I mentioned earlier calls that the major operators were generally proceeding with their development in the Gulf of Mexico kind of despite the slow pace of permitting It was the independents that I was a little concerned about and quite frankly, over the last quarter, we're seeing the independents start to move out, get permits approved and proceed with their projects. In the third quarter, we booked about 3 subsea trees related to the Gulf of Mexico but the Gulf of Mexico was strong particularly we had a good aftermarket business in the Gulf of Mexico in addition to the 3 trees. And you're right, I think typically the Gulf of Mexico is more onesie, twosies because they have the infrastructure They're tying back to it as opposed to say West Africa where you're going to have a much larger complex projects. So, yes, smaller orders in the Gulf and I'm encouraged, we have to be somewhat cautiously optimistic about the Gulf but it looks like it's starting to come back.

componenttext: John, so what was encouraging about your opening commentary year was the continued optimistic outlook regarding the subsea tree award for Seascape in this matter. What I'd like to do is maybe just oppose where you stood on the Q2 call when you pretty much revealed that you have the subsea awards will be at 50% industry-wide in 2012 and major project awards could double. You didn't specify on this call but certainly the commentary was affirmative. How would you juxtapose your outlook on the Q2 call versus today? Has that changed? Is it more optimistic or is it still the same, which is constructive.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bill, it's the same and let me kind of give the statistics again It looks like in 2011, major projects over $100 million they'll be somewhere like 8 to 10 awards in 2011. When I look at the project list for 2012, it is 20 plus and perhaps just as importan
componenttext: Bill, it's the same and let me kind of give the statistics again It looks like in 2011, major projects over $100 million they'll be somewhere like 8 to 10 awards in 2011. When I look at the project list for 2012, it is 20 plus and perhaps just as importantly, it's more evenly distributed over the year and more than half of those 20 plus awards are at least scheduled to be awarded in the first half of the year. So even if they move out a quarter, so they can still say in the year And the second thing with regard to the 20 plus projects, many of them are well into the tendering process and so they're at this stage where the vis--vis has been submitted or they're under evaluation So that gives us the confidence that not only is the number of projects over $100 million for 2012 larger than 2011 but the likelihood of them being awarded is strong. The other thing is that in 2011, there was a very little Petrobras activity. If you remember, physical, Petrobras came up with multiyear contracts. Those multiyear contracts are largely be completed or consumed and we believe the Petrobras in 2012 needs to start ordering trees and manifolds not only for the conventional equipment but also for pre-salt. So you kind of put that together plus, maybe some improvement in the Gulf of Mexico and you get a very strong 2012 for subsea awards.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well the $3.8 billion backlog that we had has kind of been in backlog for 6 months. So we're starting to get deeper into the manufacture cycle so I think it will start to ramp up in 2012. But I think typically, we are beginning backlog, we consume about 6
componenttext: Well the $3.8 billion backlog that we had has kind of been in backlog for 6 months. So we're starting to get deeper into the manufacture cycle so I think it will start to ramp up in 2012. But I think typically, we are beginning backlog, we consume about 60%, we convert about 60% of that in the year in which that backlog exists. So I don't think the $3.8 billion is unusual It's not. We had pretty good inbound in the first half besides it's evenly distributed, not is going to affect the conversion rate that's been our store growth rates.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then how much was the non-manufacturing subsea order number in the quarter, the installation service et cetera.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We actually had -- in the quarter, we had a fairly strong installation number. It represented a little over 30% of our subsea inbound. It was unusual because we booked 2 extensions to our Statoil Light Well Intervention orders and so that drove that numbe
componenttext: We actually had -- in the quarter, we had a fairly strong installation number. It represented a little over 30% of our subsea inbound. It was unusual because we booked 2 extensions to our Statoil Light Well Intervention orders and so that drove that number up. Typically the number is between 20% to 25% is our aftermarket or installation services versus the subsea inbound number that was higher in the quarter because of the unusual multiyear extension to 2 Light Well Intervention contracts with Statoil

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up on that, what do you think the prospects are for getting another Light Well Intervention unit signed up with an operator for next year?
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up on that, what do you think the prospects are for getting another Light Well Intervention unit signed up with an operator for next year?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot of interest. Our 3 Light Well Intervention systems 2 for Statoil 1 for BP are performing extremely well, utilization numbers are quite high. We've been successful in actually using the onetime contract with BP for Shell and some other
componenttext: Well, there's a lot of interest. Our 3 Light Well Intervention systems 2 for Statoil 1 for BP are performing extremely well, utilization numbers are quite high. We've been successful in actually using the onetime contract with BP for Shell and some other operators. So the interest is growing. The trigger for an additional Light Well Intervention stock will come when we're convinced that we have enough commitment for the operators to support a good level of utilization. And we don't have that yet. Right now, we got interest we got other people, other operators that are actually using the system in pleased but haven't put together enough movement to trigger a forward step. We're hopeful that I mean as the interest grows that will eventually happen.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally for me, we've had some commentary out of some pressure pumping contractors over the past few days that would suggest that market is perhaps peaking at least in the gas basin around the country. What's your current order visibility f
componenttext: Okay. And then finally for me, we've had some commentary out of some pressure pumping contractors over the past few days that would suggest that market is perhaps peaking at least in the gas basin around the country. What's your current order visibility for Fluid Control and what's your game plan if that market does soften up a bit?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well as you know, Joe, the Fluid Control business is kind of the ups in the subsea and we refer to as the shorter cycle business. So if there were a downturn in North America pressure pumping activity, we've see it fairly quick in Fluid Control but in the
componenttext: Well as you know, Joe, the Fluid Control business is kind of the ups in the subsea and we refer to as the shorter cycle business. So if there were a downturn in North America pressure pumping activity, we've see it fairly quick in Fluid Control but in the quarter, we have record levels of inbound for our Fluid Control business and the operators are continuing with a strong order rate for that equipment. So we haven't seen any kind of decline. And certainly, the shift from Gas to Liquids makes North America activity a little bit more sustained, I'll let Bob make some additional comments.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well I think John's comments were about the path forward in North America. Quite honestly, our best measure though is the active dialogue with the pressure bombers and we stay in constant contact with those guys assessing their not only their CapEx plans
componenttext: Well I think John's comments were about the path forward in North America. Quite honestly, our best measure though is the active dialogue with the pressure bombers and we stay in constant contact with those guys assessing their not only their CapEx plans but also where they're operating and how actively they're operating. And all indications are right now, that while they are somewhat less optimistic about the natural gas part of North America drilling, the liquid rich shales are certainly picking up the pace. And then there's a lot of variables that are hard to predict, leasehold drilling, gas deals where they have hedge contracts So there's a lot of moving parts but all in all, we remain a reasonably optimistic about the North American market.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from Bill Sanchez with Howard Weill.
componenttext: And your next question is from Bill Sanchez with Howard Weill.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, I wanted to talk a little bit about pricing subsea and how you see that unfolding. At the commentary previously has been for you that pricing is be relatively flat here. And just curious, as we move to 2012, given the exceptional order rate easy at
componenttext: John, I wanted to talk a little bit about pricing subsea and how you see that unfolding. At the commentary previously has been for you that pricing is be relatively flat here. And just curious, as we move to 2012, given the exceptional order rate easy at the industry as a whole, at what point do we see our competitors feeling up have backlog you're aware as the industry as a whole starts to see some sort of pricing action. And then second, can it come soon enough kind of give an even spread rate you see next year for orders to impact 2012 at all perhaps in the back half or is that more of a 2013 margin impact as you see it?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think to see a material increase in pricing, we need to see some of these major awards being distributed over to the other subsea suppliers. As you know, Bill, we rebuild our backlog with almost 60% market share in 2010 and now it looks like another 60%
componenttext: I think to see a material increase in pricing, we need to see some of these major awards being distributed over to the other subsea suppliers. As you know, Bill, we rebuild our backlog with almost 60% market share in 2010 and now it looks like another 60%-plus market share in 2011. So we rebuilt our backlog. We're going to be selective going into this very strong market for 2012 to be sure that we preserve our margins, if not improve our pricing. So we're going to be selective. But the key to a material price increase in subsea will be those other suppliers who have not rebuild their backlog and I'm sure they need to do that, so they need a couple of awards for each supplier to date where they start feeling that their backlogs are sufficiently rebuilt and then we'll start to see at least I hope anyway, that we'll start to see some pricing change as the other suppliers realize that they're starting to fill up their capacity. So I don't want to necessarily predict the timing and the calendar but I think its safe to say that we're going to have to see a handful, maybe 4 or 5 major awards left next year and distributed over the remaining some supplier before we see some pricing improvement. And I think that sort of means that could be later in the year possibly and then would have to be able to convert those orders with better pricing, pretty darn fast to get into 2012 revenues. So I think it's better to look at it more of 2013 situation.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up, I know you touched briefly on kind of the fluid in business and its relationship to North America. I'm curious if you could talk a little bit about your North American plans on the surface side. I noted that the segment that's typicall
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up, I know you touched briefly on kind of the fluid in business and its relationship to North America. I'm curious if you could talk a little bit about your North American plans on the surface side. I noted that the segment that's typically heavily weighted towards international but you guys made a conscious effort to grow that business here Just curious and what's been an uncertain WTI landscape here. Has there been more challenges in growing that business than you thought? How do you see the North America surface business unfolding for you as we move to next year?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate the question. You're actually right. Historically, our service business had been more weighed on the international side where we have very strong positions. But because of the North America activity, we've seen substantial growth and in
componenttext: Well, I appreciate the question. You're actually right. Historically, our service business had been more weighed on the international side where we have very strong positions. But because of the North America activity, we've seen substantial growth and in fact, the surface well inbound increase has come almost exclusively from North America and that's because of our success in participation in the shale plays. In particular, we've got a lot of success in frac rental equipment and throughout the year, we've increased our investment in these assets. So I think it's been very, very positive for us, allowed us to increase our market share in North America, and we've been able to us what the growth especially in this frac rental equipment. So I think, I don't necessarily want to put in North America activity but I think quarter-over-quarter, we saw big improvement in surface wallet.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess whatever you believe that rig count is going to do next year that business should grow at a faster clip for you?
componenttext: Sure. I guess whatever you believe that rig count is going to do next year that business should grow at a faster clip for you?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just want to comment on what the rig count is I let Bob comment work for --
componenttext: Yes, I just want to comment on what the rig count is I let Bob comment work for --

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of points, quarter-over-quarter, North America service well order increased 45%. So it's a big jump. The other change that has really happened in North America shales are the makeup of our customer base. Increasingly, we see more majors and
componenttext: Just a couple of points, quarter-over-quarter, North America service well order increased 45%. So it's a big jump. The other change that has really happened in North America shales are the makeup of our customer base. Increasingly, we see more majors and LOCs in the shale plays that we think plays well for us. And that's really more dead center for our kind of customer base and so that's working well for us. And as John said we're continuing to invest aggressively, not only in equipment to be utilized on the drilling applications but also in facilities, We continue to expand our footprint particularly in the liquids rich shale environment.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: And your next version is from Brad Handler with Credit Suisse.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can we please back to the Energy Production Systems margins. I guess I just want, I know you basically addressed it in your comments but maybe we can flesh it out a bit more. You had expectations of improvement in the third quarter, which were not quite r
componenttext: Can we please back to the Energy Production Systems margins. I guess I just want, I know you basically addressed it in your comments but maybe we can flesh it out a bit more. You had expectations of improvement in the third quarter, which were not quite realized and you're dampening your expectations for the fourth quarter margins, if I understood the guidance correctly, can you confirm that and is this about -- have projects fallen on back each of other so there's still delays in getting what you expected out the door it sounds like there's a little of that but can you talk about these execution issues that you are describing as such?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brad this is Bill. Let me see if I can kind of address your question. First of all, you're right. Our guidance had implied about a 13% margin in the second half of 2011, Q3 and Q4. And our current results in Q3 plus our guidance for Q4 would imply a
componenttext: Sure, Brad this is Bill. Let me see if I can kind of address your question. First of all, you're right. Our guidance had implied about a 13% margin in the second half of 2011, Q3 and Q4. And our current results in Q3 plus our guidance for Q4 would imply about 11.5% margin. So we have reduced our expectations. We've talked a fair amount about the surface issues that we've had. We've had some execution issues on our international business, those have reduced the magnitude but we're still suffering a little bit on the international side of the service business. We expect that by the end of the year that will be remediated. Then comes subsea third quarter and in subsea, I want to be pretty specific here. Let's talk about the top line first It wasn't pricing. The projects we're executing today were generally priced a year ago. It has been entirely our execution. And we had some unplanned expenses in the quarter and we expect those expenses to continue at least through the fourth quarter associated with increased volume. We had revenues of $683 million in then first quarter, we expect $1 billion in the fourth quarter, that's a 45% increase I think in activity from the first quarter to fourth quarter. We've hired 1,500 employees from subsea, up 20% increase in our population. And we haven't executed as well as we anticipated. And that's largely the reason for the reduction from kind of the 11.5% area. And we expect those added expenditures to go away based on increased efficiency of the workforce as we get used  to operating at this higher level. And that's kind of the what happened in the second half of the year.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: Okay. That's a very helpful. componenttext: Yes.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: Okay. Interesting. If I could still one more, John you expressed the confidence about still getting to $4 billion in orders but it does sound like it's kind of hinging on one large project. Am I reading that correctly or maybe you can give us a little more color about that one, I'm sure if it's what I'm thinking, I know there's some controversy about around that project moving forward.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well let me -- we're saying approaching $4 billion but we think we can get pretty close in part because really, throughout the year, we've had pretty good inbound from cool-offs and smaller awards and the third quarter is a good example that we entered $7
componenttext: Well let me -- we're saying approaching $4 billion but we think we can get pretty close in part because really, throughout the year, we've had pretty good inbound from cool-offs and smaller awards and the third quarter is a good example that we entered $731 million without a project over $150 million. So assuming that we stay in that range of a small call-offs, and then we add the remainder of Prelude, which was not entered in the third quarter and we definitely expect the remainder of Prelude, which is an amount we still need to spend for that project that being added in the fourth quarter, and then we had a major award, which I'll talk more about, you can get to over $1 billion and that starts to get closer to the $4 billion that we've been talking about. Now what that was that major award? Well, there's 3 that could potentially be awarded in the fourth quarter. Gas pump from the Stockman project. The is under evaluation. It has a chance to get into the fourth quarter probably maybe the lower probability just because it's gas pump and they haven't done a lot of subsea projects. In Western Australia, that project has been tendered under evaluation for the over months. I know the target was originally for that to be awarded in the fourth quarter. So that's still a possibility. And then there's Chevron Wheatstone where the bids have been submitted. It's been under evaluation recently Chevron announced their approval of the go-ahead for that project and I have a lot of confidence that the Wheatstone project in particular will be awarded in the fourth quarter. We're in good positions on all 3 of those projects so we're hopeful that one of those will result in a large order that we need to get close to the $4 billion.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: John, I wanted to explore a little bit the Fluid Control segment. And try to get a better handle on given the shift in kind of the U.S. tracking business. How much of your orders do you think in that business are for capital equipment versus how much of that is for maintaining equipment as the plumbing works out?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Typically, the mix is 75% consumable, 25% capital. Also typically it's in the third and fourth quarter where the pressure pumping companies start to finish their budgets and they start to release some of the CapEx. We actually saw a couple of capital orde
componenttext: Typically, the mix is 75% consumable, 25% capital. Also typically it's in the third and fourth quarter where the pressure pumping companies start to finish their budgets and they start to release some of the CapEx. We actually saw a couple of capital orders in the third quarter. We'd expect maybe some more in the fourth quarter. But typically, its a 75%, 25% consumable CapEx.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Bob. I think that's correct particularly at it relates to flow in products but our capital spending component is larger now because of the well service pump element of what we do for the pressure.pumpers as well as the big articulated frac arm m
componenttext:
This is Bob. I think that's correct particularly at it relates to flow in products but our capital spending component is larger now because of the well service pump element of what we do for the pressure.
pumpers as well as the big articulated frac arm manifolds that we've been providing both of which are more CapEx related side. So I'd say we're moving towards in total of 50-50, still 75% as John said expendables when you're talking flow line but overall, probably closer to 50-50.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. And notwithstanding the capital orders that you mentioned that you're hearing from the customer in terms of the order flow for new equipment is it starting to tail off yet or is it strong?
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. And notwithstanding the capital orders that you mentioned that you're hearing from the customer in terms of the order flow for new equipment is it starting to tail off yet or is it strong?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's still a strong. I think that if you look around basin by basin, there's still some major basins out of particularly in the liquid rich environments that are still undercapitalized if you will, in terms of equipment to be able to -- for the pressure p
componenttext: It's still a strong. I think that if you look around basin by basin, there's still some major basins out of particularly in the liquid rich environments that are still undercapitalized if you will, in terms of equipment to be able to -- for the pressure pumpers to meet the demands that they're faced with. On the other hand, there's some of the more gas rich shales where they probably have access equipment they're looking to moving things around but quite honestly, we're still continuing to see strong order flow. Admittedly, a short cycle business and again, as I said that earlier, most of our market intelligence comes from just active dialogue on ongoing basis with all the major pressure pumpers and our other customers and that continues to hold up pretty well.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: Great. Thanks. And how would you characterize the duration of your backlog there?

componenttext: Well we've got a record backlog in Fluid Control. We turned that product pretty quickly out of there I tell you, particularly on the flow line side of the business. Now on the on the pump side obviously those are longer lead times and most of our backlog, I might add is the longer lead time type of product. the other stuff just flow in very, very quickly. So that backlog we'll be consuming over the course of the next 12 months.

componenttext: Great. Thanks. And thens shifting back to subsea. One of the things apart from Marlim that I wanted to explore are other subsea processing projects any kind of update on what you see on the horizon there? Either incremental stages to Marlim or other operators around the world?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well let's start with Petrobras in Marlim. Petrobras is very, very interested in the Marlim pilot project. They're going to get the system in the water within the next couple of weeks, exactly how long they run the pilot I'm not sure but I know that they'
componenttext: Well let's start with Petrobras in Marlim. Petrobras is very, very interested in the Marlim pilot project. They're going to get the system in the water within the next couple of weeks, exactly how long they run the pilot I'm not sure but I know that they're going to obviously want to monitor and make sure it's performing. But then they'll be very anxious to start expanding the application of that technology so there's some other wells I can't predict when would that happen but I'm assuming the pilot goes well that we should expect that to happen. So they're very interested and it's very important to them and again, we should expect that once the pilot is complete, to go move ahead and apply that technology to their other fields with some of the applications similar. On the non-Petrobras processing opportunities, in 2000 -- there's 1 or 2 that could possibly be still awarded at the end of this year but looking forward to 2012 there's 10 processing projects split evenly between Brownfield and Greenfield, maybe the majority is bursting but there's at least 4 or 5 that has separation components to it. These move around a lot and 10 will survive in 2012 but that's a big jump from the 3 or 4 projects that were typically on our resin for any given year in the past.

componenttext: John, In the past, we've had some conversation, you had suggested that of those, you mentioned those 3 large project the Wheatstone, the Stockman, the and then obviously there's still the project that's out there. Would you still characterize it in that same context or do you think that is going to take more than that to see some pricing improvement?

componenttext: Yes, no, it's the same. I don't know if it's exactly 3 year it's 4, if the is distributed We pick up more than our fair share and that would still leave another supplier maybe without their backlog or where they want but I think we've got -- I think for many of them to launch and this would even be true for us but to launch multiple big EPC contracts simultaneously is a pretty big strain on the organization. And so if a supplier were to win and  2 major EPC contracts in the same quarter, they probably have to scramble and that might influence their decision on pricing. So yes, I think it will be that handful of early big projects and how distributed to the subsea suppliers will start to shape when pricing start to improve.

How would you address that?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: Well we would as the market leader, we think just the opposite. We are showing leadership on the pricing side. And I think I referred to it earlier by building our backlog to a large extent through our frame agreements with our suppliers we're in a position to be selective on certain projects that are coming up and to demonstrate that leadership as we've done on a number of projects that we walked away from last year because we weren't satisfied with the pricing while others picked that up and some of the mode notable ones are Petrobras multiyear award. Although we're the market leader in Brazil, we chose to focus on the higher end technology projects rather than the more price-sensitive conventional equipment. So I think we have demonstrated strongly our leadership by walking away from certain projects that don't meet our price expectations and focusing on where we are shown on the high technology side where we can earn better margins and I think Marlim is a wonderful example of that We're supporting Petrobras on a high end equipment where we can get better pricing.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: And so during the quarter, with the strength of the dollar, those projects that were in backlog declined by I think $308 million. So if you took our beginning backlog at the end in Q2 and then adder our inbound, subtracted our sales, you'd still have to take $308 million off to make it all fit to the $8 billion that we ended the quarter with. Now that's backlog. When it flows through our income statement for instance in the Norwegian krona contract, we've got costs in dollars, euros and pounds. And so we hedge all of those back end and So the contract itself has revenue and costs. So we don't have any margin exposure to currency but when it does flow through the income statement, if the dollar strengthens, it comes through as lower sales and lower earnings but the same margin as a percent.

componenttext: Really just wanted to ask a question that Bill's probably aimed at you. On your expense side, can you give us just a little bit of color around what pushes that you're seeing there? So this really is not a backlog question, it's the current level of cost and to the extent that if labor were a factor into this really kind of along the lines of labor rates and availability and bidding on materials to the extent various grades of steel that you guys are using forgings, et cetera, and also related then to the logistics side?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Quite frankly, we haven't seen much push on the material cost side. We are expecting some next year and we're preparing for that and most of our budgets will reflect that but year-to-date, we haven't seen much. And I can say, kind of the problem is a
componenttext: Yes. Quite frankly, we haven't seen much push on the material cost side. We are expecting some next year and we're preparing for that and most of our budgets will reflect that but year-to-date, we haven't seen much. And I can say, kind of the problem is a little bit more labor inflation than we anticipated. We're having a hard time finding people and that's part of what's caused that problem in subseas. We haven't been able to hire engineers fast enough and consequently, we've fallen little bit behind and when that happens cost begin to accumulate And that is part of what happened in the second half of 2011.
